                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer1024548092" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer14898267005325693077">
                    10 ans dans l'histoire d'une ville New York de 1963 à 1973 : en pleine mutation socio-ethnique la cité sauvage donne l'image d'une ville qui sombre dans la criminalité.
                    <br/>
                    Dans une écriture journalistique à laquelle il
                    <br/>
                    Faut s'habituer l'auteur décidé de déjouer les apparences pour écrire une contre histoire de la ville. Si criminalité il y a elle est aussi et peut être avant tout le fait d'un racisme assumé et d'une police affectée par la corruption à grande échelle. Entre erreur judiciaire et coups
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1024548092" onclick="updateMoreLink('14898267005325693077'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText14898267005325693077" style="display:none">
                    10 ans dans l'histoire d'une ville New York de 1963 à 1973 : en pleine mutation socio-ethnique la cité sauvage donne l'image d'une ville qui sombre dans la criminalité.
                    <br/>
                    Dans une écriture journalistique à laquelle il
                    <br/>
                    Faut s'habituer l'auteur décidé de déjouer les apparences pour écrire une contre histoire de la ville. Si criminalité il y a elle est aussi et peut être avant tout le fait d'un racisme assumé et d'une police affectée par la corruption à grande échelle. Entre erreur judiciaire et coups tordus des irlandais du NYPD on assiste à l'évolution du mouvement des droits civiques et à sa radicalisation au cours des années 60. Arrivés à un point de non retour au début de la décennie suivante on assiste à une ébauche de sortie de crise qu'on devine temporaire et fragile. Une contre histoire de New York, de l'Amérique afro-américaine en pleine radicalisation et un pavage vers ce qu'est devenue la ville aujourd'hui. Très très haletant et intéressant.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText14898267005325693077').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText14898267005325693077'); Element.show('freeTextContainer14898267005325693077'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>

              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_706490069" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/706490069" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1664392-richard" title="Richard">
                 <img alt="Richard" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1238012859p2/1664392.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/706490069?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Sep 20, 2014
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/1664392-richard" title="Richard">
                   Richard
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1664392-richard?shelf=new-york-city">
                    new-york-city
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1664392-richard?shelf=true-crime">
                    true-crime
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1664392-richard?shelf=african-american">
                    african-american
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer706490069" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer5716971561004565521">
                    T. J. English takes a look at racial strife and police corruption in New York City roughly between the years 1963 and 1973. I wasn't aware of any of the three main subjects that he profiled, and can't say I was surprised by any of the events he related. (I certainly hope that this kind of stuff isn't going on any longer, but I suspect it is. Hopefully, at least, it's to a much lesser degree.)
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    An interesting book, but, although it sounds like I'm nitpicking, there were some obvious, but minor erro
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/706490069" onclick="updateMoreLink('5716971561004565521'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText5716971561004565521" style="display:none">
                    T. J. English takes a look at racial strife and police corruption in New York City roughly between the years 1963 and 1973. I wasn't aware of any of the three main subjects that he profiled, and can't say I was surprised by any of the events he related. (I certainly hope that this kind of stuff isn't going on any longer, but I suspect it is. Hopefully, at least, it's to a much lesser degree.)
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    An interesting book, but, although it sounds like I'm nitpicking, there were some obvious, but minor errors that I noticed that made me wonder how many errors I wasn't noticing. Two examples: English says that the Polo Grounds were torn down in 1960, but I know that's wrong because the Mets were still playing there in 1963. And he says that Richard Nixon was sworn in as the 36th president on January 9, 1969. I know this is wrong because I live in the United States and know that Inauguration Day is January 20. (Also, Nixon was the 37th president, not the 36th.) I can overlook the Polo Grounds error more easily than the Inauguration Day error. It makes me wonder if anyone proofread the book.
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText5716971561004565521').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText5716971561004565521'); Element.show('freeTextContainer5716971561004565521'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

                        I looked the TPF up in the index, and only a few pages are devoted to it. English uses words like "brutal" and "despised" in those few pages.              <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_225781803" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/225781803" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1998675-stacia" title="Stacia">
                 <img alt="Stacia" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1268785085p2/1998675.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/225781803?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Oct 24, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/1998675-stacia" title="Stacia">
                   Stacia
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1998675-stacia?shelf=nonfiction">
                    nonfiction
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1998675-stacia?shelf=2011">
                    2011
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer225781803" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer7287677322513964955">
                    This is one of the best books of the year. The author examines a single decade in New York's history (1963-1973) by focusing on the lives of three men: George Whitmore, a man who is coerced into a 61-page confession, none of which is true; Dhoruba Bin Wahad, a key member of the Black Panthers and Black Liberation Army; and Bill Phillips, a notoriously bent cop whose testimony before the Knapp Commission exposed the rampant, widespread corruption within the NYPD. English uses these stories to ill
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/225781803" onclick="updateMoreLink('7287677322513964955'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText7287677322513964955" style="display:none">
                    This is one of the best books of the year. The author examines a single decade in New York's history (1963-1973) by focusing on the lives of three men: George Whitmore, a man who is coerced into a 61-page confession, none of which is true; Dhoruba Bin Wahad, a key member of the Black Panthers and Black Liberation Army; and Bill Phillips, a notoriously bent cop whose testimony before the Knapp Commission exposed the rampant, widespread corruption within the NYPD. English uses these stories to illustrate the growing racial tensions within New York City and the entrenched corruption of its (mostly white Irish Catholic) police force during the turbulent Civil Rights Era.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This is a well-written, well-researched, well-documented book. Yes, the events English describes took place almost a half century ago, but the conditions he describes--frustrated minority populations, corrupt system of justice, and economic inequality--still exist today, which is part of why this book is so compelling.
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText7287677322513964955').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText7287677322513964955'); Element.show('freeTextContainer7287677322513964955'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

                      flag
                     </a>
                     <span class="likeItContainer" id="like_container_review_225781803">
                      <a href="/rating/voters/225781803?resource_type=Review" id="like_count_review_225781803" rel="nofollow">
                       <span class="likesCount">
                        1 like
                       </span>
                      </a>
                      ·
                      <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F9581485-the-savage-city" rel="nofollow">
                       like
                      </a>
                     </span>
                     ·
                     <a href="/review/show/225781803?book_show_action=true&amp;page=1">
                      see review
                     </a>
                    </div>
                    <div id="comments_for_review_225781803" style="display: none;">

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_206705527" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/206705527" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/965714-lisa" title="Lisa">
                 <img alt="Lisa" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1232374675p2/965714.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/206705527?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Sep 21, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/965714-lisa" title="Lisa">
                   Lisa
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer206705527" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer282489192623973386">
                    This book was extremely timely. Given Troy Davis' pending execution in Georgia, an upcoming mayoral race in NYC, a looming presidential election and the current status NYC is enjoying as "one of the safest cities in America" - It is hyper important to remember how awful things really are for so many.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    While I loved the subject of this book, I'm less convinced that I would have loved the book if race, crime and NYC history weren't so important to me.  The writing is fairly uneven here, if face pace
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/206705527" onclick="updateMoreLink('282489192623973386'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText282489192623973386" style="display:none">
                    This book was extremely timely. Given Troy Davis' pending execution in Georgia, an upcoming mayoral race in NYC, a looming presidential election and the current status NYC is enjoying as "one of the safest cities in America" - It is hyper important to remember how awful things really are for so many.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    While I loved the subject of this book, I'm less convinced that I would have loved the book if race, crime and NYC history weren't so important to me.  The writing is fairly uneven here, if face paced and easy to read, but the stories are so compelling. I knew virtually nothing about George Whitmore, Phillips or Dhoruba, but in all honesty, I wish the book had been solely about Whitmore and his struggle. He is a horrible and important reminder of how many lives have been ruined by the prejudice and recklessness of this city's police force, by racial injustice and by the criminal justice system, which is stacked against those who have the least.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Props must be given to the author for paying such great care to telling this story properly, contextualizing the era and historical reasons for these people's lives and for remembering, always, that the problem of police brutality and lack of access to justice within the criminal justice system remains a horrible, persistent problem.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText282489192623973386').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText282489192623973386'); Element.show('freeTextContainer282489192623973386'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">
             </div>
             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_157484270" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/157484270" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/876421-beverly" title="Beverly">
                 <img alt="Beverly" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1386630133p2/876421.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/157484270?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Jun 21, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/876421-beverly" title="Beverly">
                   Beverly
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer157484270" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer11366413783346257334">
                    In The Savage City by T.J. English, the author has written an impressive narrative that exposes the gritty side of New York City. Starting with two seemingly unrelated events that occurred on August 28, 1963, Mr. English explores the issues of race, class, criminal justice, and corruption in one of the most volatile periods in New York City history, allowing the city to earn the name, The Savage City. One event is the Martin Luther King Jr. “I Have a Dream” speech on the steps of the Lincoln Mem
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/157484270" onclick="updateMoreLink('11366413783346257334'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText11366413783346257334" style="display:none">
                    In The Savage City by T.J. English, the author has written an impressive narrative that exposes the gritty side of New York City. Starting with two seemingly unrelated events that occurred on August 28, 1963, Mr. English explores the issues of race, class, criminal justice, and corruption in one of the most volatile periods in New York City history, allowing the city to earn the name, The Savage City. One event is the Martin Luther King Jr. “I Have a Dream” speech on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, which inspired action and hope in many Americans to initiate change to make the nation a better place. The other event is the murder of two young white, professional women in their Manhattan apartment, a gruesome crime given the name, The Career Girls Murder case, which put fear in the hearts of many New Yorkers who felt they were no longer safe.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The Savage City unravels this painful tale through the lives of three diverse men – who never met each other, yet each was part of this landscape and had very public faces/roles. The most tragic figure of the three is George Whitmore Jr., who is 19 years old when he is arrested and charged in the Career Girls Murder, not because he is guilty but because he is naïve and the police is all powerful and only wants to check this case off the list. Bill Phillips is a second-generation cop, who cannot wait to get to shake down businesses and police to supplement his measly police salary, but will his brazenness and police honor code allow him to avoid public scrutiny. For Dhoruba bin Wahad finding few opportunities for a young, black male turns to petty crime and is incarcerated where his introspectiveness leads him to militant activism and one of the founders of the New York Black Panthers party. Through the vibrant voices of the three men, and the well-written narrative, I was able to be caught up in the swirl of police brutality and the racial unrest that were so part of the lives of many black Americans that lived during this time. Change is always difficult, and unfortunately, usually involves violence to make the necessity of change understood. All three of the men did spend time in prison and are alive today, and it would be interesting to hear their voices and views today on how much change has taken place, as cases of uncalled for police brutality have surfaced over the last couple of years.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    I recommend this book for anyone who is interested in the history of this era, and especially for those who thought that the battlefields of the Civil Rights and black militarism were taking place in the South and West.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This book was provided by the publisher for review purposes.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Reviewed by Beverly
                    <br/>
                    APOOOBookClub
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText11366413783346257334').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText11366413783346257334'); Element.show('freeTextContainer11366413783346257334'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_156896772" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/156896772" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2209914-caitlin" title="Caitlin">
                 <img alt="Caitlin" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1239417820p2/2209914.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/156896772?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Apr 07, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/2209914-caitlin" title="Caitlin">
                   Caitlin
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2209914-caitlin?shelf=2011">
                    2011
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer156896772" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer463218846212800123">
                    I don't know about you, but when I think of the true crime genre it conjures up tacky little paperbacks that were thrown together as quickly as possible to leach the maximum income from the tragedy of others.  They tend to be poorly written and their most notable feature is often the photos of crime scenes and dead and brutalized bodies that should never have been exposed to the public.  Ghoulish and opportunistic and not something I typically read.  I'll admit that Anne Rule is slightly above most
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/156896772" onclick="updateMoreLink('463218846212800123'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText463218846212800123" style="display:none">
                    I don't know about you, but when I think of the true crime genre it conjures up tacky little paperbacks that were thrown together as quickly as possible to leach the maximum income from the tragedy of others.  They tend to be poorly written and their most notable feature is often the photos of crime scenes and dead and brutalized bodies that should never have been exposed to the public.  Ghoulish and opportunistic and not something I typically read.  I'll admit that Anne Rule is slightly above most in the genre, but only slightly.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This is not to say that all true crime sucks.  There are plenty of people writing interesting books about crime that include great history, put whatever crime they explore within its sociocultural context, and inform the reader rather than playing on their basest prurient impulses.  In this category fall books like
                    <em>
                     Helter Skelter
                    </em>
                    and
                    <em>
                     The Devil in the White City
                    </em>
                    .  T.J. English writes books like this - books that combine social history, crime, and good storytelling.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    I first discovered Mr. English when I read
                    <em>
                     Havana Nocturne
                    </em>
                    , a wonderful book about the mob in Cuba and their collision with Castro's revolution.  It was well-written and absolutely fascinating and caused me to go look for everything Mr. English had written.  He is most interested in intersections between gangs of one sort or another and the rest of the neighborhood around them.  His first book,
                    <em>
                     The Westies
                    </em>
                    , was a brilliant look at the notorious Coonan Crew placing them into context with history of the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood (now sanitized and renamed Clinton) and in late sixties/early seventies New York.  The relationship between these Irish gangbangers and the Gambino family offers a picture of the violence and insanity of the groups minusthe Hollywood romanticism.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    I was very excited to receive an advance copy of English's latest book,
                    <em>
                     The Savage City
                    </em>
                    examining a similar time period as
                    <em>
                     The Westies
                    </em>
                    , but a different set of neighborhoods and actors.  English tells the interlinked stories of three men caught on the cusp of radical social change and the evolution of a city.  Detailed, fascinating, and insightful, English brings the world of criminals, radical political activists, and the police into sharp focus.
                    <em>
                     The Savage City
                    </em>
                    examines the social forces that came together to create the New York we see today and the people caught in the whirlwinds of change.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    An excellent read for anyone interested in historical crime and violence and/or social history, in general.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText463218846212800123').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText463218846212800123'); Element.show('freeTextContainer463218846212800123'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">
                  <tr class="no_border" id="update_comment_stuff_Review156896772">

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">
             </div>
             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_176671302" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/176671302" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3102249-nycdreamin" title="Nycdreamin">
                 <img alt="Nycdreamin" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1262975070p2/3102249.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/176671302?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Jun 14, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/3102249-nycdreamin" title="Nycdreamin">
                   Nycdreamin
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer176671302" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer1458837608331313303">
                    This is a story about the policing of a city. Not just any city, New York City. And not the "safe big city" NYC is known as now. This is a tale of the city back when it had some grit and character - some swagger - and some really deep rooted problems that made men and ruined others, mostly determined on the color of their skin - this in a "progressive" city. This is a story of New York City politics and racial relations between those in power and the average citizen of color on the street of New
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/176671302" onclick="updateMoreLink('1458837608331313303'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText1458837608331313303" style="display:none">
                    This is a story about the policing of a city. Not just any city, New York City. And not the "safe big city" NYC is known as now. This is a tale of the city back when it had some grit and character - some swagger - and some really deep rooted problems that made men and ruined others, mostly determined on the color of their skin - this in a "progressive" city. This is a story of New York City politics and racial relations between those in power and the average citizen of color on the street of New York City between the late 1950's and 1970's - heavy stuff. T.J. English's latest, "Savage Streets: Race, Murder and a Generation On The Edge" eaxmines a time when racial issues between the then mostly white NYPD and the then increasingly Black and Hispanic populations of the city were at at boiling point.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    One man, some would call him uneducated and simple, leaves his home by a dump in Wildwood, New Jersey to look for a better life in early 60's era NYC. This man becomes the ultimate victim of a racist and corrupt pre-reform era NYPD through a set of circumstances he never could have imagined when he left home that day. Ultimately, he will lose years of his life to the legal system for a crime he was coerced into confessing to. This is his story.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    One man is on the beat...a New York City cop. He's also on the make. He's also a dirty cop. He draws his weekly salary, but he's shaking down money all over town. And he's the kind of cop who put men like the simple man mentioned above away out of convenience when it suited him. This cop was not alone in his attitudes, he had an entire cadre of brothers who were in on the deal and felt the same way he did about those of other questionable racial backgrounds. He is a dirty cop who eventually gets caught - then - becomes one of the biggest turncoats in the history of the New York police department, singlehandedly putting large cracks in the "Blue Wall of Silence", testifying to the leveles of corruption and racial bias then so prevalent throughout the NYPD. This dirty cop would be the catalyst for some of the changes to come in the New York police department over the coming decades. This is his story.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    One man finds himself incarcerated, then freed. He is a smart man and is hyper-aware of the fact that change is coming to America and coming fast - a change in attitudes of racial relations. This man is inspired by others, powerful men with important things to say, to rise up and educate himself and to ascend to a postition of leadershp and great influence within one of the leading radical militant organizations in the city at that time. He is determined to help the struggle for racial equality in America by any...ANY...means necessary. This is his story.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Three men with very different tales. New York was a different place then and "The Savage City" paints an amazingly clear picture of what those times could be like for members of the minority community. The book also shows how change came, eventually, slowly, painfully. "The Savage City" is a mind blowing document of a city and a time that to many readers born after 1970 or so will seem like a fiction. Sadly though, this story was the reality of the times in those days of the 1960's and 70's. Days that seem so long ago but when you get right down to it, they weren't that long ago at all.
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText1458837608331313303').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText1458837608331313303'); Element.show('freeTextContainer1458837608331313303'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_873506030" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/873506030" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25882000-joe" title="Joe">
                 <img alt="Joe" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1409083690p2/25882000.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/873506030?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Mar 06, 2014
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/25882000-joe" title="Joe">
                   Joe
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25882000-joe?shelf=history">
                    history
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer873506030" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer10866915538728319860">
                    The author of Paddy Whacked and Havana Nocturne turns his attention to New York City during the turbulent 1960's - specifically 1963-1973. English narrates a fascinating story of the "city that never sleeps" during this time through the prism of crime, civil rights/racial tensions and police corruption/brutality by chronicling the trials and travails of three men - George Whitmore, Bill Phillips and Dhoruba bin Wahad. And although the men never met, the three were at the center of the maelstrom
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/873506030" onclick="updateMoreLink('10866915538728319860'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText10866915538728319860" style="display:none">
                    The author of Paddy Whacked and Havana Nocturne turns his attention to New York City during the turbulent 1960's - specifically 1963-1973. English narrates a fascinating story of the "city that never sleeps" during this time through the prism of crime, civil rights/racial tensions and police corruption/brutality by chronicling the trials and travails of three men - George Whitmore, Bill Phillips and Dhoruba bin Wahad. And although the men never met, the three were at the center of the maelstrom of this "hard to put down" social history of the city and the country itself.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Dhoruba is an ex-con, black militant/ former Black Panther, who fought the system and "the Man", with guns and words. Phillips was a NYC cop, who spent most of his waking hours using his badge padding his meager salary - no scam or scheme too far-fetched if it put money in his pocket. Whitmore, the quintessential victim, was coerced into confessing to three violent crimes - including the brutal murders of two young women in their East Side apartment - the all but forgotten "Career Girl Murders". Whitmore's story is the toughest to read - he seemingly never got a break and for each step forward he made, he took six back, leading to despair and disaster. (Ironically - and fortuitously - his alibi for the Career Girl Murders was that he was glued to the television set at work watching MLK deliver his "I have a dream" speech.)
                    <br/>
                    Using these personal stories, the author chronicles the Civil Rights movement, including a fascinating mini-history of the Black Panthers. Phillips' story, and his eventual testimony and arrest, highlights the pervasive racism within the NYPD and the department's wide-spread corruption, up to and including the DA's office and even judges and juries. Whitmore was the pawn caught between these two forces, in and out of jail and courtrooms, tried and retried, acquitted and found guilty - a barometer of the times.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This is the author's best book to date - a fascinating read chronicling a very difficult time.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText10866915538728319860').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText10866915538728319860'); Element.show('freeTextContainer10866915538728319860'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">
                  <tr class="no_border" id="update_comment_stuff_Review873506030">
                   <td colspan="2">
                    <div class="updateActionLinks">
                     <a class="right flag" href="/flagged/new?resource_id=873506030&amp;resource_type=Review&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F9581485-the-savage-city" id="flag_link873506030" rel="nofollow" title="Flag this review as inappropriate.">
                      flag
                     </a>
                     <span class="likeItContainer" id="like_container_review_873506030">
                      <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F9581485-the-savage-city" rel="nofollow">
                       like
                      </a>
                     </span>
                     ·
                     <a href="/review/show/873506030?book_show_action=true&amp;page=1">
                      see review
                     </a>

              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_207983214" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/207983214" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/662042-mike-lindgren" title="Mike Lindgren">
                 <img alt="Mike Lindgren" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1311876567p2/662042.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/207983214?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Sep 13, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/662042-mike-lindgren" title="Mike Lindgren">
                   Mike Lindgren
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/662042-mike-lindgren?shelf=nonfiction">
                    nonfiction
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer207983214" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer5227517157633825931">
                    True-crime maven English captures New York's decade-long slide into political violence, corruption, and chaos during the years 1963–1973. The topic matter is in my wheelhouse, and English has shaped an astounding amount of research into a wonderfully gritty and streetwise narrative. Unfortunately, the effect is marred by abundantly clichéd writing: news "spreads like wildfire," "insult is added to injury," etc. Famed Harper editor Cal Morgan apparently asleep at the switch.
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

                 <div class="reviewText stacked">

                   <span id="freeTextContainer9347943815063674839">
                    This book gave me immense clarity about a period of time in which I was too young to comprehend.  I was exposed to some of it but I never knew just how bad it was.  This book should be taught in schools.  I encourage EVERYONE to read this book.  As the author states, not much has changed and we need to wake up and be that change!
                   </span>
                  </span>

                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer1002662559" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer15750882762857053899">
                    a little over a year ago i saw this book at a shop in brooklyn and took a photo of its cover because it seemed like something i would be into. i thought it was a story about the career girls murders of 1963, but how wrong i was. it was something much more in my wheelhouse - the story of three different men who have ties to new york city, nypd, the black panthers, the justice system, and institutional racism over a decade chronicling the 60s and 70s. that is everything i want to read about. well-
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1002662559" onclick="updateMoreLink('15750882762857053899'); return false;">

                   <span id="freeText15750882762857053899" style="display:none">
                    a little over a year ago i saw this book at a shop in brooklyn and took a photo of its cover because it seemed like something i would be into. i thought it was a story about the career girls murders of 1963, but how wrong i was. it was something much more in my wheelhouse - the story of three different men who have ties to new york city, nypd, the black panthers, the justice system, and institutional racism over a decade chronicling the 60s and 70s. that is everything i want to read about. well-written and engaging, i tore through this. it was great in the most dispiriting way possible, which is what i say about everything.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    sometimes judging a book by its cover (and knowing your preferred topic areas) is totally okay.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText15750882762857053899').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText15750882762857053899'); Element.show('freeTextContainer15750882762857053899'); return false;">
                     (less)

                </a>

                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">

                  </a>

                   Laurie Thurston

                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/16974269-laurie-thurston?shelf=nonfiction">
                    nonfiction
                   </a>

                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/16974269-laurie-thurston?shelf=adult-fiction">

                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer839748659" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer1267896355460258408">
                    This is an interesting history of crime in New York during the tumultuous decade between the early '60s through the early '70s. English explores the institutional racism that permeated New York City's streets, police precincts and courtrooms through the lens of three different men: two who suffered from these injustices and one who triumphed...for a while, anyway. Told through a detached, journalistic eye, English captures a crazy time in our country's history with a focus on what was once known
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/839748659" onclick="updateMoreLink('1267896355460258408'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText1267896355460258408" style="display:none">
                    This is an interesting history of crime in New York during the tumultuous decade between the early '60s through the early '70s. English explores the institutional racism that permeated New York City's streets, police precincts and courtrooms through the lens of three different men: two who suffered from these injustices and one who triumphed...for a while, anyway. Told through a detached, journalistic eye, English captures a crazy time in our country's history with a focus on what was once known as a Savage City.  Personally, I like a bit more emotional connection to non-fiction, but this is a good read.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText1267896355460258408').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText1267896355460258408'); Element.show('freeTextContainer1267896355460258408'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_628558914" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/628558914" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2953336-holly" title="Holly">
                 <img alt="Holly" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1258493037p2/2953336.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/628558914?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Jun 08, 2013
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/2953336-holly" title="Holly">
                   Holly
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer628558914" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer2347938651296615412">
                    I would actually give this book 3 1/2 stars, but I'm bumping it up instead of down...
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    It is a nonfiction account of New York City in the 1960s and 1970s, which focuses on the racism and corruption of the police department. It is centered around three people: Bill Phillips (corrupt cop), George Whitmore, Jr. (a young African-American wrongfully accused of murder, rape, and all sorts of other crimes that he "confesses" to), and Richard Moore (aka Dhoruba bin Wahad, one of the founders of the New Yo
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/628558914" onclick="updateMoreLink('2347938651296615412'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText2347938651296615412" style="display:none">
                    I would actually give this book 3 1/2 stars, but I'm bumping it up instead of down...
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    It is a nonfiction account of New York City in the 1960s and 1970s, which focuses on the racism and corruption of the police department. It is centered around three people: Bill Phillips (corrupt cop), George Whitmore, Jr. (a young African-American wrongfully accused of murder, rape, and all sorts of other crimes that he "confesses" to), and Richard Moore (aka Dhoruba bin Wahad, one of the founders of the New York Black Panthers).  Through the stories of these three men, English paints a picture of the "savage city" that New York was at that time, in contrast to the city it has now become--one of the safest large cities.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The book definitely held my interest throughout. However, the narratives of these three men didn't have a strong enough thread to hold them together. The book, therefore, came across a bit disjointed. Also, since from the beginning of the book English had stated that New York City has transformed over the course of 40 years or so into one of the safest cities, I expected a bit more explanation of how that came to be. Unfortunately this explanation occurs only on the last few pages, and essentially English states that there are still major problems of racism and brutality in the NYC police department. So basically, things haven't changed much. Yet, the city has become much safer... It sort of undermines his premise from the start of the book which was to link the savagery of NYC to the actions of the police department at the time.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Still, it was a good read, so I'd recommend it with some reservations.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText2347938651296615412').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText2347938651296615412'); Element.show('freeTextContainer2347938651296615412'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">
                  <tr class="no_border" id="update_comment_stuff_Review628558914">
                   <td colspan="2">
                    <div class="updateActionLinks">
                     <a class="right flag" href="/flagged/new?resource_id=628558914&amp;resource_type=Review&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F9581485-the-savage-city" id="flag_link628558914" rel="nofollow" title="Flag this review as inappropriate.">
                      flag
                     </a>
                     <span class="likeItContainer" id="like_container_review_628558914">
                      <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F9581485-the-savage-city" rel="nofollow">
                       like
                      </a>
                     </span>
                     ·
                     <a href="/review/show/628558914?book_show_action=true&amp;page=1">
                      see review
                     </a>
                    </div>
                    <div id="comments_for_review_628558914" style="display: none;">

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">
             </div>
             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_784113442" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/784113442" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2910056-matt" title="Matt">
                 <img alt="Matt" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1282693683p2/2910056.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/784113442?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Dec 21, 2013
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/2910056-matt" title="Matt">
                   Matt
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer784113442" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer12392288837198869971">
                    New York City in the 1960s and 1970s was a tumultuous place and English captures that very well by following three separate people through trials and tribulations in the tri-state area and beyond. One is a corrupt cop looking to squeeze as much as he can out of the streets, one is an unsuspecting black man framed by almost every level of law enforcement in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and the final is a black nationalist hell bent on revenge against a racist system. The three never meet face to face,
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/784113442" onclick="updateMoreLink('12392288837198869971'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText12392288837198869971" style="display:none">
                    New York City in the 1960s and 1970s was a tumultuous place and English captures that very well by following three separate people through trials and tribulations in the tri-state area and beyond. One is a corrupt cop looking to squeeze as much as he can out of the streets, one is an unsuspecting black man framed by almost every level of law enforcement in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and the final is a black nationalist hell bent on revenge against a racist system. The three never meet face to face, but their stories and actions affect each other directly.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    English's style in this book is narrative non-fiction and it is riveting throughout. He spend just the right amount on each person before switching to the next to keep your attention. You learn a lot about these three individuals, but English does an excellent job of tying in the overall history of not only the New York area but also the nation at a critical time in its history.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    All in all a great book and there's not much that I can think of in terms of criticisms.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText12392288837198869971').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText12392288837198869971'); Element.show('freeTextContainer12392288837198869971'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">
                  <tr class="no_border" id="update_comment_stuff_Review784113442">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_156129983" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/156129983" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1614402-lumumba-shakur" title="Lumumba Shakur">
                 <img alt="Lumumba Shakur" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1329812686p2/1614402.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/156129983?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Feb 20, 2012
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/1614402-lumumba-shakur" title="Lumumba Shakur">
                   Lumumba Shakur
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=current-events">
                    current-events
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=history">
                    history
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=civil-rights-movement">
                    civil-rights-movement
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=political-science">
                    political-science
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=african-american-studies">
                    african-american-studies
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1614402-lumumba-shakur?shelf=favorites">
                    favorites
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer156129983" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer4984932266860697046">
                    This is book is far better than I had originally expected. I was hoping it would give me some insight into the environment around which my parents grew up that lead them to join the Black/Brown Power Movement - it did that and so much more. This book is a fascinating documentation of the generational shift that occurred as the Civil Rights Movement moved north and entered into metropolitan areas. It is not just a tale of corruption and violent revolution, but a city at a time when the racial ten
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/156129983" onclick="updateMoreLink('4984932266860697046'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText4984932266860697046" style="display:none">
                    This is book is far better than I had originally expected. I was hoping it would give me some insight into the environment around which my parents grew up that lead them to join the Black/Brown Power Movement - it did that and so much more. This book is a fascinating documentation of the generational shift that occurred as the Civil Rights Movement moved north and entered into metropolitan areas. It is not just a tale of corruption and violent revolution, but a city at a time when the racial tensions boiled over and exploded. The South had Jim Crow, the North had a system of racial oppression that was in its own ways more profound and devastating to the underprivileged communities. If this book does nothing other than debunk the continued social lie that the South is where racism was rooted, it would be enough. Though somewhat of a true-life crime novel, this book should stand alongside
                    <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6792458.The_New_Jim_Crow__Mass_Incarceration_in_the_Age_of_Colorblindness" title="The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness by Michelle Alexander">
                     The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness
                    </a>
                    and other such works devoted to explaining how alive and well institutional racism still is in contemporary America. If people don't make the connection between then and now, they have missed English's entire point. The detail and thorough of this book is amazing and the way that English gives the living history of a generation through the real-life, personal experiences of three individuals is brilliant. It is an eye-opener and is definitively on my recommended reading list.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText4984932266860697046').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText4984932266860697046'); Element.show('freeTextContainer4984932266860697046'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review nosyndicate" id="review_160405667" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/160405667" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1577641-alicia" title="Alicia">
                 <img alt="Alicia" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1362550383p2/1577641.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/160405667?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Apr 13, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/1577641-alicia" title="Alicia">
                   Alicia
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer160405667" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer1277457244874451514">
                    I would give this a 5 for the amount of information I learned about the 60's in New York. And I would give it a 1 for language and subject matter (meaning there is really strong language and really difficult, violent acts discusses throughout). So it averages at a 3. But this book really opened my eyes to the fact that the "north" isn't as great as I thought it was. I mean, I know that the 60's in the south under Jim Crow was a horrible place to live. But Brooklyn and Harlem during that time was
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/160405667" onclick="updateMoreLink('1277457244874451514'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText1277457244874451514" style="display:none">
                    I would give this a 5 for the amount of information I learned about the 60's in New York. And I would give it a 1 for language and subject matter (meaning there is really strong language and really difficult, violent acts discusses throughout). So it averages at a 3. But this book really opened my eyes to the fact that the "north" isn't as great as I thought it was. I mean, I know that the 60's in the south under Jim Crow was a horrible place to live. But Brooklyn and Harlem during that time wasn't so great either. The police corruption was out of control and people were framed for things all the time. This is when the Black Panthers came to be, and their history is shocking.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Anyway, this book weaves together 3 different stories, all being told at the same time, about 3 different men during that time. One, a simple boy from Jersey who is framed for 4 crimes (3 murders and an assault). Also it's about a crooked cop who brings down the system from the inside and is also framed for murder by those same bad cops. And finally, about a man who becomes very involved in the Black Panther Party and is also sent to prison for crimes he didn't commit.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This book really opened my eyes to the fact that the 60's were a rough time for everyone involved. I'm kind of happy I didn't live in NY during that time.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText1277457244874451514').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText1277457244874451514'); Element.show('freeTextContainer1277457244874451514'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review nosyndicate" id="review_199153019" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/199153019" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5748390-jami" title="Jami">
                 <img alt="Jami" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1309972033p2/5748390.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/199153019?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Sep 27, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/5748390-jami" title="Jami">
                   Jami
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer199153019" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer2765064848539671649">
                    This book was recommended to me by someone who knows how much I love New York.  This is a gritty tale of NYC during the latter days of the Civil Rights Movement to the dawn of the Black Militanism.  It's also a tale of crooked cops, rampant racism, and one innocent man whose life is destroyed by his own naivete.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    At 500+ pages, this is a lot of book.  However, TJ English tries diligently to make weave a story of three men sacked by circumstances seemingly out of their control.  Unfortunately, the vast
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/199153019" onclick="updateMoreLink('2765064848539671649'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText2765064848539671649" style="display:none">
                    This book was recommended to me by someone who knows how much I love New York.  This is a gritty tale of NYC during the latter days of the Civil Rights Movement to the dawn of the Black Militanism.  It's also a tale of crooked cops, rampant racism, and one innocent man whose life is destroyed by his own naivete.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    At 500+ pages, this is a lot of book.  However, TJ English tries diligently to make weave a story of three men sacked by circumstances seemingly out of their control.  Unfortunately, the vast scope of the story gets bogged down in massive amounts of research and eye-witness testimony.  I don't really care about four pages of what a young TASK cop thinks he saw during a summer riot as much as what both sides were feeling leading up to the riot.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    It has been a summer of reading about race and I'm a bit pooped.  This heavy-handed, over-researched tome may have been the thing to break me of it!
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    However, I won't dismiss this book all together.  It is very interesting as far as learning about the Black Panthers (East Coast) wanted to accomplish and how it fell into in-fighting as well as how the BP was used as a scapegoat at a time when NYPD corruption was about to explode in the papers.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The story of George Whitmore, an innocent man bullied and prosecuted and convicted of crimes he did not commit, gets severely overshadowed in this book.  When I'm ready, I will probably read another book about his case.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText2765064848539671649').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText2765064848539671649'); Element.show('freeTextContainer2765064848539671649'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="elementListBrownSeparator">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_446791722" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/446791722" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2327871-khris-sellin" title="Khris Sellin">
                 <img alt="Khris Sellin" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1242576882p2/2327871.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/446791722?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Nov 19, 2012
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/2327871-khris-sellin" title="Khris Sellin">
                   Khris Sellin
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer446791722" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer6374856126935894831">
                    This book focuses on NYC in the '60s and '70s, when racial tensions were at an all-time high and the NYPD was filled with crooked cops.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The author mainly follows the lives of three people:
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    1) George Whitmore, a young black man from Wildwood, NJ, described as a "simpleton," who was easily led by the NYPD through a false confession to two rapes in Brooklyn and a sensational double homicide known as "The Career Girl Murders" in NYC, and how it took years to unravel the mess and finally get him out o
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/446791722" onclick="updateMoreLink('6374856126935894831'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText6374856126935894831" style="display:none">
                    This book focuses on NYC in the '60s and '70s, when racial tensions were at an all-time high and the NYPD was filled with crooked cops.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The author mainly follows the lives of three people:
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    1) George Whitmore, a young black man from Wildwood, NJ, described as a "simpleton," who was easily led by the NYPD through a false confession to two rapes in Brooklyn and a sensational double homicide known as "The Career Girl Murders" in NYC, and how it took years to unravel the mess and finally get him out of prison and cleared of any wrongdoing in any of these crimes.  (Interesting anecdote: His story was supposed to be made into a feature film but instead was chiseled down to a TV movie, where all names were changed, and it instead focused on a cop who "knew from the beginning" that this man was innocent - ended up being the pilot for the Kojak TV series.)
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    2) Bill Phillips, one of the most corrupt NYPD cops during that time frame, who had no shame and no apologies for his actions, until Serpico and the Knapp Commission brought him down and he turned into a "snitch" to try to save himself, only to be accused later of another double homicide.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    3) Dhoruba bin Wahad, a small-time criminal who became a big player in the Black Panther movement and later a founding member of the Black Liberation Army. He believed MLK was an ineffective leader, too passive for the changes and the revolution that needed to occur.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    So hard to imagine what a war zone the city was in those days.  English does a great job of fleshing out the history and weaving these stories together, mostly to get an understanding of how the unfortunate George Whitmore was railroaded into a murder rap.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    For my courthouse friends, our own John F. Keenan makes an appearance in the book too, as a top assistant DA during the time of the Black Panther trials.
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText6374856126935894831').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText6374856126935894831'); Element.show('freeTextContainer6374856126935894831'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

                      flag
                     </a>
                     <span class="likeItContainer" id="like_container_review_446791722">

                       like
                      </a>
