             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_159768280" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/159768280" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4317406-trishnyc" title="Trishnyc">
                 <img alt="Trishnyc" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1299636766p2/4317406.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/159768280?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Apr 10, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/4317406-trishnyc" title="Trishnyc">
                   Trishnyc
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
                   Shelves:
                   <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4317406-trishnyc?shelf=best-of-2011">
                    best-of-2011
                   </a>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer159768280" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer14074558252839012196">
                    On August 28th 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. would stand on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C to deliver a speech about the direction forward for people of color in America. He would enumerate the ways in which people of color had been subjected to indignities and humiliations and how he believed it was to the benefit of all Americans to stand up and fight these injustices. The content of this speech has been chronicled over the years and will continue to be so but on that day,
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/159768280" onclick="updateMoreLink('14074558252839012196'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText14074558252839012196" style="display:none">
                    On August 28th 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. would stand on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C to deliver a speech about the direction forward for people of color in America. He would enumerate the ways in which people of color had been subjected to indignities and humiliations and how he believed it was to the benefit of all Americans to stand up and fight these injustices. The content of this speech has been chronicled over the years and will continue to be so but on that day, events were percolating that would lead to the devastation of a young man's life and go against the very things that King hoped could one day be achieved.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    It is believed that at about time the speech was rounding up or not long after, someone broke into the home of Emily Hoffert and Janice Wylie on Manhattan's upper east side, savagely murdering both women. Their murder was so brutal, so unrelenting in its cruelty that the city of New York was thrown into a turmoil of fear and suspicion. Scores of men were pulled in for questioning and eventually released and no viable suspects emerged, adding to the city's insecurity. On the day the murders were being committed, George Whitmore Jr. was miles away in Wildwood New Jersey watching King's speech and as transfixed by its content as most of America. Months later George would find himself accused of the murder of these innocent young women who had since been dubbed "Career Girls" and would sign a sixty one page confession that supposedly detailed his crimes. He was vilified in the media as a merciless monster and rapist. What wasn't immediately apparent was the way this so called confession was obtained and how a young man who was just trying to please would  spend ten years trying to clear his name. What started out as George trying to help a cop by answering his questions resulted in a frame up job that would involve numerous detectives, and prosecutors who failed to ask the right questions despite their misgivings.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This is one of those books that make you go from anger, to despair to just plain exhaustion as you read about the ways that human beings devastate each others lives. At the time of these murders, New York had been undergoing a radical shift in its demographics as many southern blacks migrated to the north in hopes of a better life. To these migrants, New York represented equality and fairness but they would soon discover that the racism here though different in its particulars was essentially similar to what they had left behind. They found that the police force that was suppose to protect them was in many cases their chief abuser. Suspects were brutally beaten, innocent men were stopped and randomly accused and women were violated all seemingly with little recourse. In addition, there was a vast network of corrupt cops who not only brutalized the citizenry but stole and extorted them out of money and possession. Bill Phillips was an example of this kind of cop and he was known to sometimes make as much as ten times his regular salary from extortion of bar owners, drunk drivers and criminals as well as innocent citizens. He became quite wealthy off his backdoor deals even opening a flight club, an endeavor that should have raised a few eyebrows if anyone cared. He would carry on his criminal activity for many years until he was eventually caught in a wire tape sting and turned witness for the prosecution.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    This is a very well written and extensively researched book that engages the reader in an extremely accessible manner. I was never bored as I read and it was on a few occasions where I felt overwhelmed by details. The author shows the problem with hatred, corruption and violence and how it taints us all, perpetrators and victims. The truth is not all New York City polices at that time were racist or corrupt but because they had colleagues who were, many innocent officers suffered the wrath of the community. And when people feel marginalized and slighted for so long, their voices silenced by weapons, both physical and institutional, they too may lose a sense of perspective and right and wrong. Violence and hatred breeds violence and hatred. It's really that simple. Reminds me of that saying "An eye for an eye and eventually everyone ends up blind". It would be nice to believe that the issues that led to the racial clashes between police and people of color during this period are now a thing of the past. But that would be a lie and simply sweeping dirt under the rug. When a Haitian immigrant is sodomized in a police station by a group of police officers, a college student is shot with seemingly no real reason, one wonders if the ghosts of New York City's past have been truly laid to rest or if they lie dormant waiting for the next round.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    **Review copy received from Amazon.com's Vine Program.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText14074558252839012196').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText14074558252839012196'); Element.show('freeTextContainer14074558252839012196'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_160786568" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/160786568" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4213936-hillary-woody" title="Hillary Woody">
                 <img alt="Hillary Woody" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1282960183p2/4213936.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/160786568?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   May 03, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/4213936-hillary-woody" title="Hillary Woody">
                   Hillary Woody
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer160786568" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer647122909769893411">
                    My first thought was that The Savage City by T.J. English read a little like an episode of Dateline. The Savage City is a well-research book, which sheds light on a time of corruption and scandal within New York’s justice system and racial tensions in the 1960’s and 1970’s. The reader is immersed in this time by learning the stories of George Whitmore—a man falsely accused of and beaten into giving confessions for crimes he didn’t commit, Bill Phillips—a very crooked cop, and Dhoruba Bin Wahad—a
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/160786568" onclick="updateMoreLink('647122909769893411'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText647122909769893411" style="display:none">
                    My first thought was that The Savage City by T.J. English read a little like an episode of Dateline. The Savage City is a well-research book, which sheds light on a time of corruption and scandal within New York’s justice system and racial tensions in the 1960’s and 1970’s. The reader is immersed in this time by learning the stories of George Whitmore—a man falsely accused of and beaten into giving confessions for crimes he didn’t commit, Bill Phillips—a very crooked cop, and Dhoruba Bin Wahad—a founding member of New York’s Black Panthers.
                    <br/>
                    A chance encounter with a cop starts Whitmore’s long battle with the police and courts and from that moment until the end of the book, English captures the sentiment of hopelessness around Whitmore’s cases. Whitmore is also the least morally ambiguous of the three men featured in the book. Because of this and the way English writes about his situation, the reader feels drawn to Whitmore and is compelled to read more about him.
                    <br/>
                    While Dhoruba and Bill Phillips have interesting stories, there is a greater distance between the reader and these players. Not that the reader won’t want to keep turning the pages, just that there is less investment in the outcome than with Whitmore.
                    <br/>
                    Sometimes unbelievable, sometimes not (you will have to keep in mind this is fact and not fiction) the stories of police corruption and wrong-doing are what is truly gripping about this book. Police kill, steal, and blackmail. And, by the way, everyone seems to know about it. They are the sort of things that make a person say, “This was just how long ago?” and “In my country?” And of course, “How different is it now?”
                    <br/>
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText647122909769893411').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText647122909769893411'); Element.show('freeTextContainer647122909769893411'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_161668664" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/161668664" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1202511-gary-quien" title="Gary Quien">
                 <img alt="Gary Quien" src="http://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/m_50x66-e89fc14c32a41c0eb4298dfafe929b65.png"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/161668664?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Apr 17, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/1202511-gary-quien" title="Gary Quien">
                   Gary Quien
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_3" title="liked it">
                   3 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer161668664" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer12650187858218568853">
                    The decades of the 1960's and '70's were unkind to New York City where the crime rate rose steadily as racial tension escalated, and demographic changes showed huge numbers of poor people of color--mostly blacks from the deep South and hispanics from Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic--arriving in New York and hoping for a better life, while many white families fled to the suburbs.
                    <br/>
                    Meanwhile the racial make-up of the New York City Police Dep't and most city officials remained resolutely whi
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/161668664" onclick="updateMoreLink('12650187858218568853'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText12650187858218568853" style="display:none">
                    The decades of the 1960's and '70's were unkind to New York City where the crime rate rose steadily as racial tension escalated, and demographic changes showed huge numbers of poor people of color--mostly blacks from the deep South and hispanics from Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic--arriving in New York and hoping for a better life, while many white families fled to the suburbs.
                    <br/>
                    Meanwhile the racial make-up of the New York City Police Dep't and most city officials remained resolutely white, and all felt increasingly beset and defensive by the tide of change and strife engulfing the city.
                    <br/>
                    "Savage City" details the fortunes of three emblematic figures from this era: a crooked and grafty white detective who's compelled to give testimony re corruption in the NYPD; an ex-con and militant founder of the NY Black Panther Party; and an illiterate black drifter who's framed by the police for a notorious murder--all three of them caught up in the negative changes transforming the city, and all three of them later serving lengthy terms in prison.
                    <br/>
                    This is a very interesting account of a trying and traumatic period in the recent history of America's greatest and most dynamic city.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText12650187858218568853').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText12650187858218568853'); Element.show('freeTextContainer12650187858218568853'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_533087725" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/533087725" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/9730742-paul" title="Paul">
                 <img alt="Paul" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1337805779p2/9730742.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/533087725?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Mar 29, 2013
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/9730742-paul" title="Paul">
                   Paul
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer533087725" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer15609499122405405361">
                    Unlike some books I review here,I actually read this one as opposed to reviewing the audiobook version. Basically this is 3 separate stories that never converge with each other and I was waiting for that hook that never came.All the stories in the book take place from the mid 1960s to the early 70s.
                    <br/>
                    Story 1- Crooked NYPD cop gets caught extorting and becomes a rat. Somehow gets convicted of a murder that seems to come out of nowhere still in prison.
                    <br/>
                    Story 2- Mildly retarded kid from Wildwood NJ mo
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/533087725" onclick="updateMoreLink('15609499122405405361'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText15609499122405405361" style="display:none">
                    Unlike some books I review here,I actually read this one as opposed to reviewing the audiobook version. Basically this is 3 separate stories that never converge with each other and I was waiting for that hook that never came.All the stories in the book take place from the mid 1960s to the early 70s.
                    <br/>
                    Story 1- Crooked NYPD cop gets caught extorting and becomes a rat. Somehow gets convicted of a murder that seems to come out of nowhere still in prison.
                    <br/>
                    Story 2- Mildly retarded kid from Wildwood NJ moves to Brownsville and is quickly picked up and intimidated by the cops to admit to a double murder and a rape that he did not do.His cases drag on for years,in and out of prison depending on what part of the appeal process he is at.The pilot for the 70s tv series Kojak is based on the murders that this guy did not commit.
                    <br/>
                    3rd story- Black Panther and Black Liberation Army member becomes more and more militant with each injustice he perceives as having been done to his people by the man.Participates in planned ambushes of NYC cops in the early 70s and is convicted.Convictions are eventually overturned and is now free. Good book if you are interested in stories of Dirty New York, but as I said I thought all 3 stories would interconnect.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText15609499122405405361').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText15609499122405405361'); Element.show('freeTextContainer15609499122405405361'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_548978402" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/548978402" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6073825-byron" title="Byron">
                 <img alt="Byron" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1313717373p2/6073825.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/548978402?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Apr 16, 2013
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/6073825-byron" title="Byron">
                   Byron
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer548978402" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer7384197069009322267">
                    A classic feel-bad story of the borderline retarded black kid who gets framed for a crime he didn't commit, and while he's down at the station they figured they'd might as well charge him with umpteen other crimes they had lying around. This is set against the backdrop of, on the one hand, the story of the world's most corrupt Irish cop, who made a shedload shaking down drug dealers and what have you and spread it around to the rest of the cops on the take, i.e. pretty much all of them, a la "Se
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/548978402" onclick="updateMoreLink('7384197069009322267'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText7384197069009322267" style="display:none">
                    A classic feel-bad story of the borderline retarded black kid who gets framed for a crime he didn't commit, and while he's down at the station they figured they'd might as well charge him with umpteen other crimes they had lying around. This is set against the backdrop of, on the one hand, the story of the world's most corrupt Irish cop, who made a shedload shaking down drug dealers and what have you and spread it around to the rest of the cops on the take, i.e. pretty much all of them, a la "Serpico," and then he got caught and ratted out the entire system as part of a state investigation, and other hand, this guy from the Black Panthers who was out shooting at cops, blowing up buildings and what have you. The whole city at the time sounded like it was a damn mess. Hence the title, I guess. Aside from maybe the story of the kid who got framed, which really is amazing, very little of this will be a revelation to people old enough to remember when it happened, or people who've read a few books, but it should be required reading for anyone young or naive enough to still trust the police.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText7384197069009322267').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText7384197069009322267'); Element.show('freeTextContainer7384197069009322267'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review nosyndicate" id="review_730440113" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/730440113" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6016605-john" title="John">
                 <img alt="John" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1313090597p2/6016605.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/730440113?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Sep 30, 2013
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/6016605-john" title="John">
                   John
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_4" title="really liked it">
                   4 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer730440113" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer13901246925463130328">
                    The history presented in this book is important and fascinating.  I especially like the author’s take on telling it: three perspectives – one a corrupt cop, one a black militant, and one an innocent bystander caught up in the horror.  It’s an effective and refreshing way to explore this period of history.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    My problems with this book are more-or-less the same as I have with many history books written for popular consumption: the prose is overly hyperbolic; the attempt to make it read like a novel is
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/730440113" onclick="updateMoreLink('13901246925463130328'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText13901246925463130328" style="display:none">
                    The history presented in this book is important and fascinating.  I especially like the author’s take on telling it: three perspectives – one a corrupt cop, one a black militant, and one an innocent bystander caught up in the horror.  It’s an effective and refreshing way to explore this period of history.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    My problems with this book are more-or-less the same as I have with many history books written for popular consumption: the prose is overly hyperbolic; the attempt to make it read like a novel is occasionally ham-handed and doesn’t serve the history as well as it should; the frequency with which the author puts thoughts into the characters heads is somewhat too liberal.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    The single biggest complaint I have about this book is the ending.  The end felt very abrupt, as though the author couldn’t figure out a good place to stop and just cut it off.  The book begins with the onset of George Whitmore's legal odyssey, so it in that sense it works to end with the dismissal of his final lingering charge.  But the epilogue makes it clear that this isn’t the end of George’s story, and 1973 certainly wasn’t anything close to the end of the troubles that ransacked this period of New York’s history, which left me feeling like the book ended before the story was actually done, without sufficient closure for the other threads of it.  There’s still so much about all of this that needs to be talked about.  Also, in the second half of the book, George Whitmore’s story largely recedes to become the least present and compelling of the three intertwined narratives, and so – while ending with his story is structurally appropriate – narratively, it feels arbitrary and somewhat irrelevant.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Overall, the book is very good.  Good enough, in fact, that I wasn’t terribly bothered by the usual pop-history stylistic quibbles I have, and I will recommend this book to people.  But the ending left me very disappointed, indeed, as though I was short-changed.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText13901246925463130328').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText13901246925463130328'); Element.show('freeTextContainer13901246925463130328'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">
                  <tr class="no_border" id="update_comment_stuff_Review730440113">

             <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown">
              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_161601658" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/161601658" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5181739-ian" title="Ian">
                 <img alt="Ian" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1388122951p2/5181739.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/161601658?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   May 05, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/5181739-ian" title="Ian">
                   Ian
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer161601658" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer17797268303215540832">
                    Incredibly well-written overview of the tumultuous decade between 1963 and 1973 and how a broken justice system, brutally dysfunctional, corrupt and racist police took the city of New York to the brink of collapse and a virtual race war. English weaves an amazing narrative around the three central characters, one an innocent man who becomes victim to the systemic racism in he legal justice system, the second a notorious digure in the Black militant movement that eventually becomes embroiled in a
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/161601658" onclick="updateMoreLink('17797268303215540832'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText17797268303215540832" style="display:none">
                    Incredibly well-written overview of the tumultuous decade between 1963 and 1973 and how a broken justice system, brutally dysfunctional, corrupt and racist police took the city of New York to the brink of collapse and a virtual race war. English weaves an amazing narrative around the three central characters, one an innocent man who becomes victim to the systemic racism in he legal justice system, the second a notorious digure in the Black militant movement that eventually becomes embroiled in a series of gun fights in NYC and the last, a crooked cop who pimped the corruption endemic  in he force until his downfall brought the entire system to an end amid his violation of the fabled 'blue wall of silence.' for many, NYC will always be the city of extreme violence, drugs, poverty and urban decay. Read how it got that way through the story of these three men. TJ English has delivered a masterpiece with The Savage City - it's a MUST-read!!!
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText17797268303215540832').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText17797268303215540832'); Element.show('freeTextContainer17797268303215540832'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

              <div class="section">
               <div class="review" id="review_171066092" itemprop="reviews" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
                <link href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/171066092" itemprop="url"/>
                <a class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/326190-sheehan" title="Sheehan">
                 <img alt="Sheehan" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/users/1242362532p2/326190.jpg"/>
                </a>
                <div class="left bodycol">
                 <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
                  <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/171066092?book_show_action=true" itemprop="publishDate">
                   Jun 01, 2011
                  </a>
                  <a class="user" href="/user/show/326190-sheehan" title="Sheehan">
                   Sheehan
                  </a>
                  rated it
                  <a class=" staticStars stars_5" title="it was amazing">
                   5 of 5 stars
                  </a>
                 </div>
                 <div class="reviewText stacked">
                  <span class="readable" id="reviewTextContainer171066092" style="">
                   <span id="freeTextContainer15176064317888202964">
                    Been having a great book month, English's well researched survey of police corruption and racial politics of the 1960's/70's is a fantastic insight into just how rotten the Big Apple was not too long ago.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Following the lives of George Whitmore (wrongly accused black man), Phillips (a crooked as the day is long NYC cop) and a politicized militant Black Panther's various intersections in NY's urban unrest of the late 60's was a novel and interesting way to show seemingly at odds perspectives at wo
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/171066092" onclick="updateMoreLink('15176064317888202964'); return false;">
                     ...more
                    </a>
                   </span>
                   <span id="freeText15176064317888202964" style="display:none">
                    Been having a great book month, English's well researched survey of police corruption and racial politics of the 1960's/70's is a fantastic insight into just how rotten the Big Apple was not too long ago.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    Following the lives of George Whitmore (wrongly accused black man), Phillips (a crooked as the day is long NYC cop) and a politicized militant Black Panther's various intersections in NY's urban unrest of the late 60's was a novel and interesting way to show seemingly at odds perspectives at work simultaneously.  Strong use of the various people's own oral and written histories of this time frame, along with copious outside research makes for a fascinating read.
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    You interested in Black Power movements, 60's radicalism and State oppression?  read this...
                    <br/>
                    Prisons and institutional racism in law?  read this...
                    <br/>
                    Police Brutality and Blue Wall of silence, or "no snitches" for cops?  read this!
                    <br/>
                    <br/>
                    I'd recommend this hands down to anyone.
                    <a class="actionLinkLite showMoreReviewText" href="#" onclick="$('freeText15176064317888202964').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText15176064317888202964'); Element.show('freeTextContainer15176064317888202964'); return false;">
                     (less)
                    </a>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </div>

             <ul>
              <li class="cover" id="bookCover_231086">
               <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/231086.The_Devil_s_Playground">
                <img alt="The Devil's Playground: A Century of Pleasure and Profit in Times Square" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1385446802m/231086.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script charset="utf-8" type="text/javascript">
                document.onclick = checkOpenSelects;

  function submitShelfLink(unique_id, book_id, shelf_id, shelf_name, submit_form, exclusive) {
    var checkbox_id = 'shelf_name_' + unique_id + '_' + shelf_id;
    var element = document.getElementById(checkbox_id)

    var checked = element.checked
    if (checked && exclusive) {
      // can't uncheck a radio by clicking it!
      return
    }
    if(document.getElementById("savingMessage")){
      Element.show('savingMessage')
    }
    var element_id = 'shelfInDropdownName_' + unique_id + '_' + shelf_id;
    Element.update(element_id, "saving...");
    if (submit_form) {
      Element.hide('shelfDropdown_' + unique_id)
      var form = document.getElementById('addBookForm' + book_id)
      if (form) {
        form.shelf.value = shelf_name
        form.onsubmit()
      }
    }
    else {
      var action = checked ? 'remove' : ''
      element.checked = !element.checked
      new Ajax.Request('/shelf/add_to_shelf', {asynchronous:true, evalScripts:true, onSuccess:function(request){shelfSubmitted(request, book_id, checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name)}, parameters:'book_id=' + book_id + '&name=' + shelf_name + '&a=' + action + '&authenticity_token=' + encodeURIComponent('s3GjW+BqGMcewWHFGfALa/KgIoa5DMJy3dbP9gnnZh0QDpEMQ4Vfs24uCW16XVEcBTdWXm3ILk/NxUaRtzd1RQ==')})
    }
  }

  function shelfSubmitted(request, book_id, checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name) {
    Element.update('shelfListfalse_' + book_id, request.responseText)
    afterShelfSave(checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name.escapeHTML())
  }

  function refreshGroupBox(group_id, book_id) {
    new Ajax.Updater('addGroupBooks' + book_id + '', '/group/add_book_box', {asynchronous:true, evalScripts:true, onSuccess:function(request){refreshGroupBoxComplete(request, book_id);}, parameters:'id=' + group_id + '&book_id=' + book_id + '&refresh=true' + '&authenticity_token=' + encodeURIComponent('MN5nxvduy00iX23RqCiDQxJAx98ZGp0ygyeZAUxbzBGToVWRVIGMOVKwBXnLhdk05dezB83ecQ+TNBBm8ovfSQ==')})
  }
               </script>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_231086'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/231086.The_Devil_s_Playground?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The Devil\'s Playground: A Century of Pleasure and Profit in Times Square<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/135107.James_Traub?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">James Traub<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.38 of 5 stars\">3.38 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.38 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.38 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.38 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.38 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.38 avg rating &mdash; 71 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2004\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer10853545569498499646\">As Times Square turns 100, New York Times Magazine contributing writer James Traub tells the story of how this mercurial district became one of the most famous and exciting places in the world. The Devil’s Playground is classic and colorful American history, from the first years of the twentieth cen<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'10853545569498499646\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText10853545569498499646\" style=\"display:none\">As Times Square turns 100, New York Times Magazine contributing writer James Traub tells the story of how this mercurial district became one of the most famous and exciting places in the world. The Devil’s Playground is classic and colorful American history, from the first years of the twentieth century through the Runyonesque heyday of nightclubs and theaters in the 1920s and ’30s, to the district’s decline in the 1960s and its glittering corporate revival in the 1990s. First, Traub gives us the great impresarios, wits, tunesmiths, newspaper columnists, and nocturnal creatures who shaped Times Square over the century since the place first got its name: Oscar Hammerstein, Florenz Ziegfeld, George S. Kaufman, Damon Runyon, Walter Winchell, and “the Queen of the Nightclubs,” Texas Guinan; bards like A. J. Liebling, Joe Mitchell, and the Beats, who celebrated the drug dealers and pimps of 42nd Street. He describes Times Square’s notorious collapse into pathology and the fierce debates over how best to restore it to life.Traub then goes on to scrutinize today’s Times Square as no author has yet done. He writes about the new 42nd Street, the giant Toys “R” Us store with its flashing Ferris wheel, the new world of corporate theater, and the sex shops trying to leave their history behind.More than sixty years ago, Liebling called Times Square “the heart of the world”—not just the center of the world, though this crossroads in Midtown Manhattan was indeed that, but its heart. From the dawn of the twentieth century through the 1950s, Times Square was the whirling dynamo of American popular culture and, increasingly, an urban sanctuary for the eccentric and the untamed. The name itself became emblematic of the tremendous life force of cities everywhere.Today, Times Square is once again an awe-inspiring place, but the dark and strange corners have been filled with blazing light. The most famous street character on Broadway, “the Naked Cowboy,” has his own website, and Toys “R” Us calls its flagship store in Times Square “the toy center of the universe.” For the giant entertainment corporations that have moved to this safe, clean, and self-consciously gaudy spot, Times Square is still very much the center of the world. But is it still the heart?From the Hardcover edition.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText10853545569498499646\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText10853545569498499646\');                <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6088116-l-a-noir">
                <img alt="L.A. Noir: The Struggle for the Soul of America's Most Seductive City" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1320438838m/6088116.jpg"/>

               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_6088116'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6088116-l-a-noir?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">L.A. Noir: The Struggle for the Soul of America\'s Most Seductive City<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/498370.John_Buntin?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">John Buntin<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.73 of 5 stars\">3.73 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.73 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.73 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.73 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.73 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.73 avg rating &mdash; 682 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2009\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer4958127293114776961\">Other cities have histories. Los Angeles has legends. Midcentury Los Angeles. A city sold to the world as \"the white spot of America,\" a land of sunshine and orange groves, wholesome Midwestern values and Hollywood stars, protected by the world’s most famous police force, the Dragnet-era LAPD. Behin<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'4958127293114776961\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText4958127293114776961\" style=\"display:none\">Other cities have histories. Los Angeles has legends. Midcentury Los Angeles. A city sold to the world as &quot;the white spot of America,&quot; a land of sunshine and orange groves, wholesome Midwestern values and Hollywood stars, protected by the world’s most famous police force, the Dragnet-era LAPD. Behind this public image lies a hidden world of &quot;pleasure girls&quot; and crooked cops, ruthless newspaper tycoons, corrupt politicians, and East Coast gangsters on the make. Into this underworld came two men–one L.A.’s most notorious gangster, the other its most famous police chief–each prepared to battle the other for the soul of the city. Former street thug turned featherweight boxer Mickey Cohen left the ring for the rackets, first as mobster Benjamin &quot;Bugsy&quot; Siegel’s enforcer, then as his protégé. A fastidious dresser and unrepentant killer, the diminutive Cohen was Hollywood’s favorite gangster–and L.A.’s preeminent underworld boss. Frank Sinatra, Robert Mitchum, and Sammy Davis Jr. palled around with him; TV journalist Mike Wallace wanted his stories; evangelist Billy Graham sought his soul. William H. Parker was the proud son of a pioneering law-enforcement family from the fabled frontier town of Deadwood. As a rookie patrolman in the Roaring Twenties, he discovered that L.A. was ruled by a shadowy &quot;Combination&quot;–a triumvirate of tycoons, politicians, and underworld figures where alliances were shifting, loyalties uncertain, and politics were practiced with shotguns and dynamite. Parker’s life mission became to topple it–and to create a police force that would never answer to elected officials again. These two men, one morally unflinching, the other unflinchingly immoral, would soon come head-to-head in a struggle to control the city–a struggle that echoes unforgettably through the fiction of Raymond Chandler and movies such as The Big Sleep, Chinatown, and L.A. Confidential. For more than three decades, from Prohibition through the Watts Riots, the battle between the underworld and the police played out amid the nightclubs of the Sunset Strip and the mansions of Beverly Hills, from the gritty streets of Boyle Heights to the manicured lawns of Brentwood, intersecting in the process with the agendas and ambitions of J. Edgar Hoover, Robert F. Kennedy, and Malcolm X. The outcome of this decades-long entanglement shaped modern American policing–for better and for worse–and helped create the Los Angeles we know today. A fascinating examination of Los Angeles’s underbelly, the Mob, and America’s most admired–and reviled–police department, L.A. Noir is an enlightening, entertaining, and richly detailed narrative about the city originally known as El Pueblo de Nuestra Se–ora la Reina de los Angeles, &quot;The Town of Our Lady the Queen of the Angels.&quot;\n\nFrank Darabont has adapted this book for a TV series, Mob City.<a href=\"#\"       var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_10593692'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/10593692-the-murder-of-jim-fisk-for-the-love-of-josie-mansfield?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The Murder of Jim Fisk for the Love of Josie Mansfield: A Tragedy of the Gilded Age<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/4645.H_W_Brands?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">H.W. Brands<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.02 of 5 stars\">3.02 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.02 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.02 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.02 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.02 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.02 avg rating &mdash; 171 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2011\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer8159056799456230204\">Even before he was shot dead on the stairway of the tony Grand Central Hotel in 1872, financier James “Jubilee Jim” Fisk, Jr., was a notorious New York City figure. From his audacious attempt to corner the gold market in 1869 to his battle for control of the geographically crucial Erie Railroad, Fis<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'8159056799456230204\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText8159056799456230204\" style=\"display:none\">Even before he was shot dead on the stairway of the tony Grand Central Hotel in 1872, financier James “Jubilee Jim” Fisk, Jr., was a notorious New York City figure. From his audacious attempt to corner the gold market in 1869 to his battle for control of the geographically crucial Erie Railroad, Fisk was a flamboyant exemplar of a new financial era marked by volatile fortunes and unprecedented greed and corruption. But it was his scandalously open affair with a showgirl named Josie Mansfield that ultimately led to his demise. In this riveting short history—the first in his American Portraits series—H. W. Brands traces Fisk’s extraordinary downfall, bringing to life New York’s Gilded Age and some of its legendary players, including Boss William Tweed, Cornelius Vanderbilt, and the railroad tycoon Jay Gould.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText8159056799456230204\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText8159056799456230204\'); Element.show(\'freeTextContainer8159056799456230204\'); return                <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/391280.The_Devil_s_Gentleman">
                <img alt="The Devil's Gentleman: Privilege, Poison, and the Trial That Ushered in the Twentieth Century" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1266541477m/391280.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_391280'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/391280.The_Devil_s_Gentleman?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The Devil\'s Gentleman: Privilege, Poison, and the Trial That Ushered in the Twentieth Century<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/51490.Harold_Schechter?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Harold Schechter<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.65 of 5 stars\">3.65 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.65 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.65 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.65 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.65 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.65 avg rating &mdash; 781 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2007\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer12693482094713404841\">From renowned true-crime historian Harold Schechter, whom The Boston Book Review hails as “America’s principal chronicler of its greatest psychopathic killers,” comes the riveting exploration of a notorious, sensational New York City murder in the 1890s, the fascinating forensic science of an earlie<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'12693482094713404841\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText12693482094713404841\" style=\"display:none\">From renowned true-crime historian Harold Schechter, whom The Boston Book Review hails as “America’s principal chronicler of its greatest psychopathic killers,” comes the riveting exploration of a notorious, sensational New York City murder in the 1890s, the fascinating forensic science of an earlier age, and the explosively dramatic trial that became a tabloid sensation at the turn of the century.Death was by poison and came in the mail: A package of Bromo Seltzer had been anonymously sent to Harry Cornish, the popular athletic director of Manhattan’s elite Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Cornish barely survived swallowing a small dose; his cousin Mrs. Katherine Adams died in agony after ingesting the toxic brew. Scandal sheets owned by Hearst and Pulitzer eagerly jumped on this story of fatal high-society intrigue, speculating that the devious killer was a chemist, a woman, or “an effeminate man.” Forensic studies suggested cyanide as the cause of death; handwriting on the deadly package and the vestige of a label glued to the bottle pointed to a handsome, athletic society scamp, Roland Molineux.The wayward son of a revered Civil War general, Molineux had clashed bitterly with Cornish before. He had even furiously denounced Cornish when penning his resignation from the Knickerbocker Club, a letter that later proved a major clue. Bon vivant Molineux had recently wed the sensuous Blanche Chesebrough, an opera singer whose former lover, Henry Barnet, had also recently died . . . after taking medicine sent to him through the mail. Molineux’s subsequent indictment for murder led to two explosive trials, a sex-infused scandal that shocked the nation, and a lurid print-media circus that ended in madness and a proud family’s disgrace.In bold, brilliant strokes, Schechter captures all the colors of the tumultuous legal case, gathering his own evidence and tackling subjects no one dared address at the time–all in hopes of answering the tantalizing question: What powerfully dark motives could drive the wealthy scion of an eminent New York family to foul murder?Schechter vividly portrays the case’s fascinating cast of characters, including Julian Hawthorne, son of Nathaniel Hawthorne, a prolific yellow journalist who covered the story, and proud General Edward Leslie Molineux, whose son’s ignoble deeds besmirched a dignified national hero’s final years. All the while Schechter brings alive Manhattan’s Gilded Age: a gaslit world of elegant town houses and hidden bordellos, chic restaurants and shabby opium dens, a city peopled by men and women fighting and losing the battle against urges an upright era had ordered suppressed.Superbly researched and powerfully written, The Devil’s Gentleman is an insightful, gripping work, a true-crime historian’s crowning achievement.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText12693482094713404841\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText12693482094713404841\');                <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/8550475-twilight-at-the-world-of-tomorrow">
                <img alt="Twilight at the World of Tomorrow : Genius, Madness, Murder, and the 1939 World's Fair on the Brink of  War" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1320479207m/8550475.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_8550475'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/8550475-twilight-at-the-world-of-tomorrow?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">Twilight at the World of Tomorrow : Genius, Madness, Murder, and the 1939 World\'s Fair on the Brink of  War<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/3401042.James_Mauro?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">James Mauro<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.58 of 5 stars\">3.58 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.58 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.58 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.58 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.58 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.58 avg rating &mdash; 221 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2010\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer5115445139756998210\">The summer of 1939 was an epic turning point for America—a brief window between the Great Depression and World War II. It was the last season of unbridled hope for peace and prosperity; by Labor Day, the Nazis were in Poland. And nothing would come to symbolize this transformation from acute optimis<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'5115445139756998210\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText5115445139756998210\" style=\"display:none\">The summer of 1939 was an epic turning point for America—a brief window between the Great Depression and World War II. It was the last season of unbridled hope for peace and prosperity; by Labor Day, the Nazis were in Poland. And nothing would come to symbolize this transformation from acute optimism to fear and dread more than the 1939 New York World’s Fair. A glorious vision of the future, the Fair introduced television, the fax machine, nylon, and fluorescent lights. The “World of Tomorrow,” as it was called, was a dream city built upon a notorious garbage dump—The Great Gatsby’s infamous ash heaps. Yet these lofty dreams would come crashing down to earth in just two years. From the fair’s opening on a stormy spring day, everything that could go wrong did: not just freakish weather but power failures and bomb threats.Amid the drama of the World’s Fair, four men would struggle against the coming global violence. Albert Einstein, a lifelong pacifist, would come to question his beliefs as never before. From his summer home on Long Island, he signed a series of letters to President Roosevelt urging the development of an atomic bomb—an act he would later recall as “the one great mistake in my life.”Grover Whalen, the Fair’s president, struggled in vain to win over dictators Benito Mussolini and Joseph Stalin, believing that his utopian vision had the power to stop their madness. And two New York City police detectives, Joe Lynch and Freddy Socha, who had been assigned to investigate a series of bomb threats and explosions that had terrorized the city for months, would have a rendezvous with destiny at the Fair: During the summer of 1940, in a chilling preview of things to come, terrorism would arrive on American shores—and the grounds of the World’s Fair. Yet behind this tragic tableau is a story as incredible as it is inspiring. With a colorful cast of supporting characters—including Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, Robert Moses, and FDR—Twilight at the World of Tomorrow is narrative nonfiction at its finest, a gripping true-life drama that not only illuminates a forgotten episode of the nation’s past but shines a probing light upon its present and its future.<a href=\"#\"               <li class="cover" id="bookCover_6004377">
               <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6004377-the-road-to-woodstock">
                <img alt="The Road to Woodstock" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1348552227m/6004377.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_6004377'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6004377-the-road-to-woodstock?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The Road to Woodstock<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/4614019.Michael_Lang?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Michael  Lang<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.01 of 5 stars\">4.01 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.01 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.01 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.01 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.01 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 4.01 avg rating &mdash; 523 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2009\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer15233380605872346527\">August 15, 1969. Richie Havens, the first act of the Woodstock Music and Art Fair, takes the stage and welcomes a crowd of several hundred thousand to the green fields of Max Yasgur\'s farm—which is quickly becoming the second-largest city in New York State. People are dancing, imbibing, meeting, and<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'15233380605872346527\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText15233380605872346527\" style=\"display:none\">August 15, 1969. Richie Havens, the first act of the Woodstock Music and Art Fair, takes the stage and welcomes a crowd of several hundred thousand to the green fields of Max Yasgur\'s farm—which is quickly becoming the second-largest city in New York State. People are dancing, imbibing, meeting, and helping the ever-increasing stream of new neighbors set up camp. Beyond the fields, the roads are jammed with cars and people, some of whom have been traveling for days to reach the festival site. Havens enthusiastically delivers folk-blues standards and Beatles songs, then begins to improvise, riffing on the refrain &quot;Freedom.&quot; Freedom is at the heart of the harmony of this landmark cultural event—along with brotherhood, love, and peace. The next three days are the realization of months and years of dreaming and planning, the result of miracles and crises and coincidences.\n\nThe story of the festival begins with Michael Lang, a kid out of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, who liked to smoke a joint and listen to jazz and who eventually found his way to Florida, where he opened a head shop and produced his first festival—Miami Pop, featuring Jimi Hendrix, Frank Zappa, and others. In the late sixties, after settling in Woodstock, he began to envision a music and arts festival where folks could come and stay for a few days amid the rural beauty of upstate New York. The idea crystallized when Lang talked it over with Artie Kornfeld, a songwriter and A &amp; R man, and with two other young men they formed Woodstock Ventures. They booked talent, from Janis Joplin and the Who to the virtually unknown Santana and Crosby, Stills and Nash; won over agents and promoters; brought in the Hog Farm commune to set up campgrounds; hired a peacekeeping force; took on fleets of volunteers; appeased the Yippies; and were run out of one town and found another site weeks before the festival.\n\nOn the ground with the talent, the townspeople, and his handpicked crew, Lang had a unique and panoramic perspective of the festival. Enhanced by interviews with others who were central to the making of the festival, The Road to Woodstock tells the story from inspiration to celebration, capturing all the magic, mayhem, and mud in between.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText15233380605872346527\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText15233380605872346527\'); Element.show(\'freeTextContainer15233380605872346527\'); return false;\">(less)<\/a><\/span>\n\n    <\/div>\n    <div class=\'wtrButtonContainer wtrSignedOut\' id=\'13_book_6004377\'>\n<div class=\'wtrUp wtrLeft\'>\n<form accept-charset=\"UTF-8\" What began as an association of convenience would fundamentally shape their political visions, propelling them further than either had dared imagine. Ironically, though, their jointly conceived vision of revolution would ultimately force them to choose between friendship and their beliefs. At a momentous turning point in Cuban history, Simon Reid-Henry offers a fascinating and original chronicle of two of the most powerful personalities in recent memory.\n  \n<a href=\"#\"                 <img alt="Island of Vice: Theodore Roosevelt's Doomed Quest to Clean up Sin-loving New York" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1328325256m/13062394.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_13062394'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/13062394-island-of-vice?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">Island of Vice: Theodore Roosevelt\'s Doomed Quest to Clean up Sin-loving New York<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/10904.Richard_Zacks?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Richard Zacks<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.55 of 5 stars\">3.55 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.55 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.55 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.55 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.55 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.55 avg rating &mdash; 905 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2012\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer10962356128919593102\">When young Theodore Roosevelt was appointed police commissioner of New York City, he had the astounding gall to try to shut down the brothels, gambling joints, and after-hours saloons. This is the story of how TR took on Manhattan vice . . . and vice won. In the 1890s, New York City was America’s fi<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'10962356128919593102\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText10962356128919593102\" style=\"display:none\">When young Theodore Roosevelt was appointed police commissioner of New York City, he had the astounding gall to try to shut down the brothels, gambling joints, and after-hours saloons. This is the story of how TR took on Manhattan vice . . . and vice won. In the 1890s, New York City was America’s financial, manufacturing, and entertainment capital, and also its preferred destination for sin, teeming with forty thousand prostitutes, glittery casinos, and all-night dives. Police cap­tains took hefty bribes to see nothing while reformers writhed in frustration.  In Island of Vice, Richard Zacks paints a vivid portrait of the lewd underbelly of 1890s New York, and of Theodore Roosevelt, the puritanical, cocksure police commissioner resolved to clean it up. Writing with great wit and zest, Zacks explores how young Roosevelt goes head to head with Tammany Hall, takes midnight rambles with muckraker Jacob Riis, and tries to convince two million New Yorkers to enjoy wholesome family fun. When Roosevelt’s crackdown succeeds too well, even his supporters turn on him, and TR discovers that New York loves its sin more than its salvation.  With cameos by Stephen Crane, Mark Twain, and a horde of very angry cops, Island of Vice is an unforgettable snap­shot of turn-of-the-century New York in all its seedy glory and a brilliant miniature of one of America’s most colorful presidents.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText10962356128919593102\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText10962356128919593102\');                 <img alt="Anatomy of Injustice: A Murder Case Gone Wrong" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1326148277m/12802037.jpg"/>

                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_12802037'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/12802037-anatomy-of-injustice?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">Anatomy of Injustice: A Murder Case Gone Wrong<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/330139.Raymond_Bonner?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Raymond Bonner<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.06 of 5 stars\">4.06 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.06 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.06 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.06 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.06 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 4.06 avg rating &mdash; 372 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2012\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer3483702756940809830\">The book that helped free an innocent man who had spent twenty-seven years on death row.In January 1982, an elderly white widow was found brutally murdered in the small town of Greenwood, South Carolina. Police immediately arrested Edward Lee Elmore, a semiliterate, mentally retarded black man with<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'3483702756940809830\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText3483702756940809830\" style=\"display:none\">The book that helped free an innocent man who had spent twenty-seven years on death row. In January 1982, an elderly white widow was found brutally murdered in the small town of Greenwood, South Carolina. Police immediately arrested Edward Lee Elmore, a semiliterate, mentally retarded black man with no previous felony record. His only connection to the victim was having cleaned her gutters and windows, but barely ninety days after the victim’s body was found, he was tried, convicted, and sentenced to death. Elmore had been on death row for eleven years when a young attorney named Diana Holt first learned of his case. After attending the University of Texas School of Law, Holt was eager to help the disenfranchised and voiceless; she herself had been a childhood victim of abuse. It required little scrutiny for Holt to discern that Elmore’s case—plagued by incompetent court-appointed defense attorneys, a virulent prosecution, and both misplaced and contaminated evidence—reeked of injustice. It was the cause of a lifetime for the spirited, hardworking lawyer. Holt would spend more than a decade fighting on Elmore’s behalf. With the exemplary moral commitment and tenacious investigation that have distinguished his reporting career, Bonner follows Holt’s battle to save Elmore’s life and shows us how his case is a textbook example of what can go wrong in the American justice system. He reviews police work, evidence gathering, jury selection, work of court-appointed lawyers, latitude of judges, iniquities in the law, prison informants, and the appeals process. Throughout, the actions and motivations of both unlikely heroes and shameful villains in our justice system are vividly revealed.             Moving, suspenseful, and enlightening, Anatomy of Injustice is a vital contribution to our nation’s ongoing, increasingly important debate about inequality and the death penalty.From the Hardcover edition.<a href=\"#\" Connor<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.28 of 5 stars\">3.28 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.28 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.28 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.28 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.28 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.28 avg rating &mdash; 256 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2009\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer17678826940989565821\">“There’s a rush to it, an elevation of the senses. . . . It’s a sweet feeling, one I’ll never get tired of, not on my twentieth heist, or my fiftieth, or my hundredth.”\n\nOnce a promising young rock musician, the son of a decorated policeman, Myles Connor became one of Boston’s most notorious criminals<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'17678826940989565821\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText17678826940989565821\" style=\"display:none\">“There’s a rush to it, an elevation of the senses. . . . It’s a sweet feeling, one I’ll never get tired of, not on my twentieth heist, or my fiftieth, or my hundredth.”\n\nOnce a promising young rock musician, the son of a decorated policeman, Myles Connor became one of Boston’s most notorious criminals—a legendary art thief with irresistible charm and a genius IQ whose approach to his chosen profession mixed brilliant tactical planning with stunning bravado, brazen disguises, audaciously elaborate con jobs, and even the broad-daylight grab-and-dash. New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Smithsonian Institution, Boston’s Museum of Fine Art . . .no museum was off-limits. The fact that he was in jail at the time of the largest art theft in American history—the still-unsolved robbery of the Isabella Stewart Gardener Museum—has not stopped the FBI from considering him a prime suspect. Optioned for film by the Oscar-winning screenwriter and director William Monahan (The Departed), The Art of the Heist is Connor’s story—part confession, part thrill ride, and impossible to put down.<a                 //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_3389089'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3389089-american-lightning?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">American Lightning: Terror, Mystery, the Birth of Hollywood &amp; the Crime of the Century<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/28419.Howard_Blum?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Howard Blum<\/a><span title=\"Goodreads Author!\">*<\/span>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.45 of 5 stars\">3.45 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.45 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.45 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.45 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.45 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.45 avg rating &mdash; 1,404 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2008\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer4756447293931107656\">It was an explosion that reverberated across the country—and into the very heart of early-twentieth-century America. On the morning of October 1, 1910, the walls of the Los Angeles Times Building buckled as a thunderous detonation sent men, machinery, and mortar rocketing into the night air. When at<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'4756447293931107656\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText4756447293931107656\" style=\"display:none\">It was an explosion that reverberated across the country—and into the very heart of early-twentieth-century America. On the morning of October 1, 1910, the walls of the Los Angeles Times Building buckled as a thunderous detonation sent men, machinery, and mortar rocketing into the night air. When at last the wreckage had been sifted and the hospital triage units consulted, twenty-one people were declared dead and dozens more injured. But as it turned out, this was just a prelude to the devastation that was to come.In American Lightning, acclaimed author Howard Blum masterfully evokes the incredible circumstances that led to the original “crime of the century”—and an aftermath more dramatic than even the crime itself. With smoke still wafting up from the charred ruins, the city’s mayor reacts with undisguised excitement when he learns of the arrival, only that morning, of America’s greatest detective, William J. Burns, a former Secret Service man who has been likened to Sherlock Holmes. Surely Burns, already world famous for cracking unsolvable crimes and for his elaborate disguises, can run the perpetrators to ground. Through the work of many months, snowbound stakeouts, and brilliant forensic sleuthing, the great investigator finally identifies the men he believes are responsible for so much destruction. Stunningly, Burns accuses the men—labor activists with an apparent grudge against the Los Angeles Times’s fiercely anti-union owner—of not just one heinous deed but of being part of a terror wave involving hundreds of bombings. While preparation is laid for America’s highest profile trial ever—and the forces of labor and capital wage hand-to-hand combat in the streets—two other notable figures are swept into the drama: industry-shaping ﬁlmmaker D.W. Griffith, who perceives in these events the possibility of great art and who will go on to alchemize his observations into the landmark film The Birth of a Nation; and crusading lawyer Clarence Darrow, committed to lend his eloquence to the defendants, though he will be driven to thoughts of suicide before events have fully played out.Simultaneously offering the absorbing reading experience of a can’t-put-it-down thriller and the perception-altering resonance of a story whose reverberations continue even today, American Lightning is a masterpiece of narrative nonfiction.<a href=\"#\" 244 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2011\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer8317221098781854812\">A 12-year-old boy cowers in his closet while a lunatic killer slaughters his family... \n\nA nursing student unwittingly opens her home to the serial killer on her front porch... \n\nAn 11-year-old girl drifts alone at sea on a flimsy cork raft for almost four days after a mass murderer kills her vacationin<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'8317221098781854812\'); From Howard Unruh\'s 1949 shooting rampage through a quiet New Jersey neighborhood to Louisiana serial killer Derrick Todd Lee\'s reign of terror in 2002, the corpses piled up and few lived to tell the horror. \n\nNow, award-winning journalist Ron Franscell explores the wounded hearts and minds of the ordinary people these monsters couldn\'t kill. His mesmerizing accounts crackle with gritty details that put the reader in the midst of the carnage-and offer a front-row seat on the complex, painful process of surviving the rest of their haunted lives. In intimate, gripping prose, Franscell takes the reader on a pulse-pounding dash through the murky intersection of pure evil and the potency of the human spirit. This journey into the darkest corners of the American crime-scape is a penetrating work of literary journalism by a writer hailed as one of the most powerful new voices in true crime.<a href=\"#\"
