              <li class="cover" id="bookCover_1099721">
               <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1099721.The_President_s_House">
                <img alt="The President's House: 1800 to the Present The Secrets and History of the World's Most Famous Home" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1320406233m/1099721.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_1099721'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1099721.The_President_s_House?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The President\'s House: 1800 to the Present The Secrets and History of the World\'s Most Famous Home<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/1559.Margaret_Truman?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Margaret Truman<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.53 of 5 stars\">3.53 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.53 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.53 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.53 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.53 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.53 avg rating &mdash; 219 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2003\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer6636690252441649245\">As Margaret Truman knows from firsthand experience, living in the White House can be exhilarating and maddening, alarming and exhausting–but it is certainly never dull. Part private residence, part goldfish bowl, and part national shrine, the White House is both the most important address in America<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'6636690252441649245\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText6636690252441649245\" style=\"display:none\">As Margaret Truman knows from firsthand experience, living in the White House can be exhilarating and maddening, alarming and exhausting–but it is certainly never dull. Part private residence, part goldfish bowl, and part national shrine, the White House is both the most important address in America and the most intensely scrutinized. In this splendid blend of the personal and historic, Margaret Truman offers an unforgettable tour of “the president’s house” across the span of two centuries.Opened (though not finished) in 1800 and originally dubbed a “palace,” the White House has been fascinating from day one. In Thomas Jefferson’s day, it was a reeking construction site where congressmen complained of the hazards of open rubbish pits. Andrew Jackson’s supporters, descending twenty thousand strong from the backwoods of Kentucky and Tennessee, nearly destroyed the place during his first inaugural. Teddy Roosevelt expanded it, Jackie Kennedy and Pat Nixon redecorated it. Through all the vicissitudes of its history, the White House has transformed the characters, and often the fates, of its powerful occupants.In The President’s House, Margaret Truman takes us behind the scenes, into the deepest recesses and onto the airiest balconies, as she reveals what it feels like to live in the White House. Here are hilarious stories of Teddy Roosevelt’s rambunctious children tossing spitballs at presidential portraits–as well as a heartbreaking account of the tragedy that befell President Coolidge’s young son, Calvin, Jr. Here, too, is the real story of the Lincoln Bedroom and the thrilling narrative of how first lady Dolley Madison rescued a priceless portrait of George Washington and a copy of the Declaration of Independence before British soldiers torched the White House in 1814. Today the 132-room White House operates as an exotic combination of first-class hotel and fortress, with 1,600 dedicated workers, an annual budget over $1 billion, and a kitchen that can handle anything from an intimate dinner for four to a reception for 2,400. But ghosts of the past still walk its august corridors–including a phantom whose visit President Harry S Truman described to his daughter in eerie detail.From the basement swarming with reporters to the Situation Room crammed with sophisticated technology to the Oval Office where the president receives the world’s leaders, the White House is a beehive of relentless activity, deal-making, intrigue, gossip, and of course history in the making. In this evocative and insightful book, Margaret Truman combines high-stakes drama with the unique perspective of an insider. The ultimate guided tour of the nation’s most famous dwelling, The President’s House is truly a national treasure.From the Hardcover edition.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText6636690252441649245\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText6636690252441649245\'); Element.show(\'freeTextContainer6636690252441649245\'); return false;\">(less)<\/a><\/span>\n\n    <\/div>\n    <div class=\'wtrButtonContainer wtrSignedOut\' id=\'21_book_1099721\'>\n<div class=\'wtrUp wtrLeft\'>\n<form accept-charset=\"UTF-8\" By looking at massacres in schools and offices as post-industrial rebellions, Mark Ames is able to juxtapose the historical place of rage i<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'1977938183607036915\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText1977938183607036915\" style=\"display:none\">Going Postal examines the phenomenon of rage murder that took America by storm in the early 1980\'s and has since grown yearly in body counts and symbolic value. By looking at massacres in schools and offices as post-industrial rebellions, Mark Ames is able to juxtapose the historical place of rage in America with the social climate after Reaganomics began to effect worker\'s paychecks. But why high schools? Why post offices? Mark Ames examines the most fascinating and unexpected cases, crafting a convincing argument for workplace massacres as modern day slave rebellions. Like slave rebellions, rage massacres are doomed, gory, sometimes inadvertently comic, and grossly misunderstood. Going Postal seeks to contextualize this violence in a world where working isn\'t—and doesn’t pay—what it used to. Part social critique and part true crime page-turner, Going Postal answers the questions asked by commentators on the nightly news and films such as Bowling for Columbine.<a href=\"#\" Compelling historical true crime, The Mad Bomber of New York is the gripping tale of two individuals engaged in a deadly game of hide-and-seek, with the city of New York caught in the crosshairs.<a               <li class="cover" id="bookCover_9507382">
               <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/9507382-popular-crime">
                <img alt="Popular Crime: Reflections on the Celebration of Violence" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1408221892m/9507382.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_9507382'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/9507382-popular-crime?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">Popular Crime: Reflections on the Celebration of Violence<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/12126.Bill_James?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Bill James<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.71 of 5 stars\">3.71 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.71 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.71 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p6\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.71 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p0\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"3.71 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 3.71 avg rating &mdash; 1,219 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2011\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer7490921070606708814\">\n  The man who revolutionized the way we think about baseball now examines our cultural obsession with murder&#8212;delivering a unique, engrossing, brilliant history of tabloid crime in America. \nCelebrated writer and contrarian Bill James has voraciously read true crime throughout his life and has be<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'7490921070606708814\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText7490921070606708814\" style=\"display:none\">\n  The man who revolutionized the way we think about baseball now examines our cultural obsession with murder&amp;#8212;delivering a unique, engrossing, brilliant history of tabloid crime in America. \nCelebrated writer and contrarian Bill James has voraciously read true crime throughout his life and has been interested in writing a book on the topic for decades. Now, with Popular Crime, James takes readers on an epic journey from Lizzie Borden to the Lindbergh baby, from the Black Dahlia to O. J. Simpson, explaining how crimes have been committed, investigated, prosecuted and written about, and how that has profoundly influenced our culture over the last few centuries&amp;#8212; even if we haven&amp;#8217;t always taken notice. Exploring such phenomena as serial murder, the fluctuation of crime rates, the value of evidence, radicalism and crime, prison reform and the hidden ways in which crimes have shaped, or reflected, our society, James chronicles murder and misdeeds from the 1600s to the present day. James pays particular attention to crimes that were sensations during their time but have faded into obscurity, as well as still-famous cases, some that have never been solved, including the Lindbergh kidnapping, the Boston Strangler and JonBenet Ramsey. Satisfyingly sprawling and tremendously entertaining, Popular Crime is a professed amateur&amp;#8217;s powerful examination of the incredible impact crime stories have on our society, culture and history.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"$(\'freeText7490921070606708814\').previous().show();Element.hide(\'freeText7490921070606708814\'); Element.show(\'freeTextContainer7490921070606708814\'); return false;\">(less)<\/a><\/span>\n\n    <\/div>\n    <div class=\'wtrButtonContainer wtrSignedOut\' id=\'24_book_9507382\'>\n<div class=\'wtrUp wtrLeft\'>\n<form accept-charset=\"UTF-8\"                <a href="http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/795301.The_Great_Upheaval">
                <img alt="The Great Upheaval: America and the Birth of the Modern World, 1788-1800" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1407276590m/795301.jpg"/>
               </a>
               <script type="text/javascript">
                //<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_795301'), "\n\n  <h2><a href=\"http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/795301.The_Great_Upheaval?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\" class=\"readable\">The Great Upheaval: America and the Birth of the Modern World, 1788-1800<\/a><\/h2>\n\n  <div>\n  by <a href=\"/author/show/31145.Jay_Winik?a=6&amp;origin=related_works\" class=\"authorName\">Jay Winik<\/a>\n  <\/div>\n  <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n    <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.04 of 5 stars\">4.04 of 5 stars<\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.04 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.04 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p10\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.04 of 5 stars\"><\/a><a class=\"staticStar p3\" size=\"12x12\" title=\"4.04 of 5 stars\"><\/a><\/span> 4.04 avg rating &mdash; 875 ratings<\/span>\n    &mdash; published 2007\n  <\/div>\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      <span id=\"freeTextContainer4596456014287952715\">It is an era that redefined history. As the 1790s began, a fragile America teetered on the brink of oblivion, Russia towered as a vast imperial power, and France plunged into revolution. But in contrast to the way conventional histories tell it, none of these remarkable events occurred in isolation.<a href=\"#\" onclick=\"updateMoreLink(\'4596456014287952715\'); return false;\">...more<\/a><\/span>\n<span id=\"freeText4596456014287952715\" style=\"display:none\">It is an era that redefined history. As the 1790s began, a fragile America teetered on the brink of oblivion, Russia towered as a vast imperial power, and France plunged into revolution. But in contrast to the way conventional histories tell it, none of these remarkable events occurred in isolation. Now, for the first time, in The Great Upheaval, acclaimed historian Jay Winik masterfully illuminates how their fates combined in one extraordinary moment to change the course of civilization.\n\nIn this sweeping, magisterial drama, Winik brings his vast, meticulous research and narrative genius to the cold, dark battlefields and deadly clashes of ideologies that defined this age. Here is a savage world war, the top-pling of a great dynasty, and an America struggling to survive at home and abroad. Here, too, is the first modern holy war between Islam and a resurgent Christian empire. And here is the richest cast of characters to walk upon the world stage: Washington and Jefferson, Louis XVI and Robespierre, Catherine the Great, Adams, Napoleon, and Selim III. With powerful echoes for understanding the international chaos that confronts the globe today, we see them all fighting desperately for the ideals they believed in, whether man-made democracy or divinely inspired autocracy, whether republicanism or Allah\'s law.\n\nExquisitely written and utterly compelling, The Great Upheaval vividly depicts an arc of revolutionary fervor stretching from Philadelphia and Paris to St. Petersburg and Cairo—with fateful results. A landmark in historical literature, Winik\'s gripping, epic portrait of this tumultuous decade will forever transform the way we see America\'s beginnings and our world.<a href=\"#\"        <div class=" clearFloats bigBox" id="aboutAuthor">
        <div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer">
         <h2 class="brownBackground">
          <a href="/author/show/904440.T_J_English">
           About T.J. English
          </a>
         </h2>
        </div>
        <div class="bigBoxBody">
         <div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <a href="/author/show/904440.T_J_English">
           <img alt="904440" class="right" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/authors/1396470409p2/904440.jpg"/>
          </a>
          <div class="readable">
           <span id="freeTextContainer13599552042903989569">
            T. J. English is an author, journalist and screenwriter with an emphasis on organized crime, the criminal underworld, and the criminal justice system. Many of his books have been national bestsellers, including THE SAVAGE CITY, HAVANA NOCTURNE, PADDY WHACKED, and THE WESTIES. In 2013, a collection of his journalism was published under the title WHITEY'S PAYBACK, an anthology that includes articles
            <a class="actionLinkLite" href="#" onclick="updateMoreLink('13599552042903989569'); return false;">
             ...more
            </a>
           </span>
           <span id="freeText13599552042903989569" style="display:none">
            T. J. English is an author, journalist and screenwriter with an emphasis on organized crime, the criminal underworld, and the criminal justice system. Many of his books have been national bestsellers, including THE SAVAGE CITY, HAVANA NOCTURNE, PADDY WHACKED, and THE WESTIES. In 2013, a collection of his journalism was published under the title WHITEY'S PAYBACK, an anthology that includes articles originally printed in Playboy, Newsweek, Esquire, New York, and other national publications. In addition, English has written episodes of the television crime dramas NYPD Blue and Homicide: Life on the Streets.
            <a class="actionLinkLite" href="#" onclick="$('freeText13599552042903989569').previous().show();Element.hide('freeText13599552042903989569'); Element.show('freeTextContainer13599552042903989569'); return false;">
             (less)
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
          <a class="actionLink moreLink" href="/author/show/904440.T_J_English">
           More about T.J. English...
          </a>
          <div class="clear">
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="bigBoxBottom">
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class=" clearFloats bigBox">
        <div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer">
         <h2 class="brownBackground">
          <a href="/author/list/904440.T_J_English">
           Books by T.J. English
          </a>
         </h2>
        </div>
        <div class="bigBoxBody">
         <div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <a href="/book/show/2578863-havana-nocturne">
           <img alt="Havana Nocturne: How the Mob Owned Cuba &amp; Then Lost it to the Revolution" id="more_book_2578863" src="http://d.gr-assets.com/books/1388636435m/2578863.jpg" title="Havana Nocturne: How the Mob Owned Cuba &amp; Then Lost it to the Revolution" width="50"/>
          </a>

        <div class="columnGroup first">
         <h6 class="kicker">
          Bookshelf
         </h6>
         <h1 class="articleHeadline">
          <nyt_headline type=" " version="1.0">
           A Nightmarish Time in the City Is Revisited
          </nyt_headline>
         </h1>
         <nyt_byline>
          <h6 class="byline">
           By
           <a class="meta-per" href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/r/sam_roberts/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More Articles by Sam Roberts">
            SAM ROBERTS
           </a>
          </h6>
         </nyt_byline>
         <h6 class="dateline">
          Published: March 18, 2011
         </h6>
         <script type="text/javascript">
          var articleToolsShareData = {"url":"http:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2011\/03\/20\/nyregion\/0320book.html","headline":"A Nightmarish Time in the City Is Revisited","description":"A new book called \u201cSavage City\u201d reconstructs the rampaging decade of the 1960s through the lives of three New Yorkers.","keywords":"Murders and Attempted Murders,Photography,Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare,Books and Literature","section":"nyregion","sub_section":null,"section_display":"N.Y. \/ Region","sub_section_display":null,"byline":"By <a href=\"http:\/\/topics.nytimes.com\/top\/reference\/timestopics\/people\/r\/sam_roberts\/index.html?inline=nyt-per\" title=\"More Articles by Sam Roberts\" class=\"meta-per\">SAM ROBERTS<\/a>","pubdate":"March 18, 2011","passkey":null};

            <div class="articleToolsSponsor" id="Frame4A">
             <!-- ADXINFO classification="Business_SF_Markets_Module_Tile" campaign="FoxSearchlight_AT2014-1911128-Oct" priority="8000" isInlineSafe="N" width="120" height="60" -->
             <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/adx/bin/adx_click.html?type=goto&amp;opzn&amp;page=www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/nyregion&amp;pos=Frame4A&amp;sn2=be39a6a9/d502c4ce&amp;sn1=9e8b2196/44c978f4&amp;camp=FoxSearchlight_AT2014-1911128-Oct&amp;ad=1013.Birdman_NYT120x60-FRIDAY&amp;goto=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2EBirdmanTheMovie%2Ecom" target="_blank">
              <img border="0" height="60" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/adx/images/ADS/38/63/ad.386338/120x60_animated_friday.gif" width="120"/>
             </a>
             <!--MOAT Standard Analytics Code starts here-->
             <script src="http://js.moatads.com/nyt952824751/moatad.js#moatClientLevel1=Studios&amp;moatClientLevel2=Fox_Searchlight_Pictures&amp;moatClientLevel3=FoxSearchlight_AT2014-1911128-Oct&amp;moatClientLevel4=1013.Birdman_NYT120x60-FRIDAY&amp;moatClientSlicer1=www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/nyregion/0320book.html&amp;zMoatAT=Standard&amp;zMoatAC=Business_SF_Markets_Module_Tile" type="text/javascript">
             </script>
             <noscript class="MOAT-nyt952824751?moatClientLevel1=Studios&amp;moatClientLevel2=Fox_Searchlight_Pictures&amp;moatClientLevel3=FoxSearchlight_AT2014-1911128-Oct&amp;moatClientLevel4=1013.Birdman_NYT120x60-FRIDAY&amp;moatClientSlicer1=www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/nyregion/0320book.html&amp;zMoatAT=Standard&amp;zMoatAC=Business_SF_Markets_Module_Tile">

           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="articleBody">
          <nyt_text>
           <nyt_correction_top>
           </nyt_correction_top>
           <p>
            T.J. ENGLISH, who chronicled Irish mobsters in “The Westies,” Vietnamese gangs in Chinatown in “Born to Kill” and the Mafia’s pre-Castro Cuba, returns with a swashbuckling, racially charged nightmare about New York City in the 1960s. This is one nightmare worth reliving because
            <a href="http://www.tj-english.com/" title="Web page about Mr. English.">
             Mr. English
            </a>
            so vividly recreates an era when, he writes, “the city was perched on the brink of self-immolation” and reminds New Yorkers how lucky they are to be living here today.
           </p>
          </nyt_text>
         </div>
         <div class="articleInline runaroundLeft">
          <div class="inlineImage module">
           <div class="image">
            <div class="icon enlargeThis">
             <a href="javascript:pop_me_up2('http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2011/03/20/nyregion/20BOOK.html','20BOOK_html','width=433,height=630,scrollbars=yes,toolbars=no,resizable=yes')">
              Enlarge This Image
             </a>
            </div>
            <a href="javascript:pop_me_up2('http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2011/03/20/nyregion/20BOOK.html','20BOOK_html','width=433,height=630,scrollbars=yes,toolbars=no,resizable=yes')">
             <img alt="" height="262" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2011/03/20/nyregion/20BOOK/20BOOK-articleInline.jpg" width="190"/>
            </a>
           </div>
           <h6 class="credit">
            Bettmann/CORBIS
           </h6>
           <p class="caption">
            <strong>
             BEDLAM
            </strong>
            Harlem in 1964. T.J. English     examines the racially charged '60s.
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="articleBody">
          <p>
           His
           <strong>
            “Savage City: Race, Murder, and a Generation on the Edge”
           </strong>
           (William Morrow, $27.99) begins in Mississippi on Oct. 2, 1944, with the first public demonstration of the mechanical cotton picker, the invention that ignites “a demographic explosion” of black migration to northern cities like New York.
          </p>
          <p>
           Over the next 400 pages, he graphically reconstructs a rampaging decade through three lives: George Whitmore Jr., a black teenager who was railroaded into confessing to the murders of two “career girls”; Bill Phillips, a “gleefully corrupt” rogue cop who turns informer for the Knapp Commission; and Dhoruba bin Wahad, the prototypically militant “Black Avenger.”
          </p>
          <p>
           All three, Mr. English writes, “became enmeshed in a similar matrix of forces — political, social and racial — that would alter the direction of the city.” Things got worse before getting much better, before New York became the Safest Big City in America. All three of Mr. English’s protagonists survived. So did the scars. “Today the city projects an image of security,” the author concludes. “But the fault lines remain.”
          </p>
          <p>
           
          </p>
          <p>
           Just in time for spring comes
           <strong>
            “Rooftop Gardens: The Terraces, Conservatories, and Balconies of New York”
           </strong>
           (Rizzoli, $45), by Denise LeFrak Calicchio and Roberta Amon, with photos by Norman McGrath that are so lifelike they could incite your sinuses if not your envy. These sanctuaries are, after all, intensely private, and ordinarily protected even from the view of ordinary mortals.
          </p>
          <p>
           “Who hasn’t walked through the streets of New York City, craning a neck to get a glimpse of penthouse life?” Dominique Browning, the former House &amp; Garden editor, writes in her introduction. “Most of us mere mortals have never had the chance to ride the thermals in the city’s stratosphere, gazing down at the terraces below — which is why a book like this is such a treasure.”
          </p>
          <p>
           
          </p>
          <p>
           It was loosely labeled Central Brooklyn, but Brian Merlis, president of
           <a href="http://www.brooklynpix.com/" title="The Web site.">
            Brooklyn Collectibles
           </a>
           , deftly slices off a mile-square neighborhood that he calls a “multidimensional time machine.” In his book
           <strong>
            “
            <a href="http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2011/02/08/brooklyn-history-buff-explores-clinton-hill-wallabout/" title="Information on the book and its author in The Local--Fort Greene.">
             Brooklyn’s Historic Clinton Hill and Wallabout
            </a>
            ”
           </strong>
           (self-published, $50), he examines the section of the city largely through historic photos of an earlier dimension that reveal the city’s largest collection of pre-Civil War frame dwellings.
          </p>
          <p>
           Like so many neighborhoods redefined by real estate brokers, its boundaries are fuzzy, “flexible lines that oscillate like guitar strings, and exist only as states of mind.”
          </p>
          <nyt_correction_bottom>
           <div class="articleCorrection">
           </div>
          </nyt_correction_bottom>
          <nyt_update_bottom>
          </nyt_update_bottom>
         </div>
        </div>
        <!--cur: prev:-->

             </h6>
            </div>

                </a>
               </li>
               <a href="/2011/03/20/nyregion/0320book.html?_r=0&amp;pagewanted=all">
               </a>
               <nyt_reprints_form>
                <script name="javascript">
                 function submitCCCForm(){
		PopUp = window.open('', '_Icon','location=no,toolbar=no,status=no,width=650,height=550,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes');
		this.document.cccform.submit();
	}
                </script>
                <li class="reprints">
                 <a href="#" onclick="submitCCCForm()">
                  Reprints
                 </a>
                </li>
               </nyt_reprints_form>
              </ul>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            writePost();
           </script>
          </div>
         </div>
